text: THE PROBLEMS OF PHILOSOPHY

author: Russell, Bertrand

text: By Bertrand Russell

author: Russell, Bertrand

text: PREFACE
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: In the following pages I have confined myself in the main to those
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: problems of philosophy in regard to which I thought it possible to say
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: something positive and constructive, since merely negative criticism
title: The Problems of Philosophy

text: seemed out of place. For this reason, theory of knowledge occupies a
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: larger space than metaphysics in the present volume, and some topics
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: much discussed by philosophers are treated very briefly, if at all.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: I have derived valuable assistance from unpublished writings of G. E.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of sense-data to physical objects, and from the latter as regards
title: The Problems of Philosophy

title: The Problems of Philosophy

title: The Problems of Philosophy

text: CHAPTER I. APPEARANCE AND REALITY
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Is there any knowledge in the world which is so certain that no
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: reasonable man could doubt it? This question, which at first sight might
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: not seem difficult, is really one of the most difficult that can
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: be asked. When we have realized the obstacles in the way of a
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: straightforward and confident answer, we shall be well launched on the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: study of philosophy--for philosophy is merely the attempt to answer
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: such ultimate questions, not carelessly and dogmatically, as we do in
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: ordinary life and even in the sciences, but critically, after exploring
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: all that makes such questions puzzling, and after realizing all the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: vagueness and confusion that underlie our ordinary ideas.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: In daily life, we assume as certain many things which, on a closer
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: scrutiny, are found to be so full of apparent contradictions that only a
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: great amount of thought enables us to know what it is that we really may
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: believe. In the search for certainty, it is natural to begin with our
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: present experiences, and in some sense, no doubt, knowledge is to be
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: derived from them. But any statement as to what it is that our immediate
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: experiences make us know is very likely to be wrong. It seems to me that
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: I am now sitting in a chair, at a table of a certain shape, on which I
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: see sheets of paper with writing or print. By turning my head I see out
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of the window buildings and clouds and the sun. I believe that the sun
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is about ninety-three million miles from the earth; that it is a hot
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: globe many times bigger than the earth; that, owing to the earth's
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: rotation, it rises every morning, and will continue to do so for an
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: indefinite time in the future. I believe that, if any other normal
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: person comes into my room, he will see the same chairs and tables and
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: books and papers as I see, and that the table which I see is the same as
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the table which I feel pressing against my arm. All this seems to be
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: so evident as to be hardly worth stating, except in answer to a man who
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: doubts whether I know anything. Yet all this may be reasonably doubted,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and all of it requires much careful discussion before we can be sure
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: that we have stated it in a form that is wholly true.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: To make our difficulties plain, let us concentrate attention on the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: table. To the eye it is oblong, brown and shiny, to the touch it is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: smooth and cool and hard; when I tap it, it gives out a wooden sound.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Any one else who sees and feels and hears the table will agree with this
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: description, so that it might seem as if no difficulty would arise;
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: but as soon as we try to be more precise our troubles begin. Although
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: I believe that the table is 'really' of the same colour all over, the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: parts that reflect the light look much brighter than the other parts,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and some parts look white because of reflected light. I know that, if
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: I move, the parts that reflect the light will be different, so that the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: apparent distribution of colours on the table will change. It follows
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: that if several people are looking at the table at the same moment, no
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: two of them will see exactly the same distribution of colours, because
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: no two can see it from exactly the same point of view, and any change in
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the point of view makes some change in the way the light is reflected.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: For most practical purposes these differences are unimportant, but to
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the painter they are all-important: the painter has to unlearn the habit
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of thinking that things seem to have the colour which common sense says
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: they 'really' have, and to learn the habit of seeing things as they
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: appear. Here we have already the beginning of one of the distinctions
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: that cause most trouble in philosophy--the distinction between
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: 'appearance' and 'reality', between what things seem to be and what they
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: are. The painter wants to know what things seem to be, the practical man
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and the philosopher want to know what they are; but the philosopher's
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: wish to know this is stronger than the practical man's, and is more
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: troubled by knowledge as to the difficulties of answering the question.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: To return to the table. It is evident from what we have found, that
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: there is no colour which pre-eminently appears to be _the_ colour of the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: table, or even of any one particular part of the table--it appears to
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: be of different colours from different points of view, and there is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: no reason for regarding some of these as more really its colour than
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: others. And we know that even from a given point of view the colour will
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: seem different by artificial light, or to a colour-blind man, or to a
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: man wearing blue spectacles, while in the dark there will be no colour
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: at all, though to touch and hearing the table will be unchanged. This
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: colour is not something which is inherent in the table, but something
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: depending upon the table and the spectator and the way the light falls
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: on the table. When, in ordinary life, we speak of _the_ colour of the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: table, we only mean the sort of colour which it will seem to have to a
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: normal spectator from an ordinary point of view under usual conditions
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of light. But the other colours which appear under other conditions
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: have just as good a right to be considered real; and therefore, to avoid
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: favouritism, we are compelled to deny that, in itself, the table has any
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: one particular colour.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: The same thing applies to the texture. With the naked eye one can see
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the grain, but otherwise the table looks smooth and even. If we looked
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: at it through a microscope, we should see roughnesses and hills and
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: valleys, and all sorts of differences that are imperceptible to the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: naked eye. Which of these is the 'real' table? We are naturally tempted
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to say that what we see through the microscope is more real, but that in
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: turn would be changed by a still more powerful microscope. If, then, we
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: cannot trust what we see with the naked eye, why should we trust what we
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: see through a microscope? Thus, again, the confidence in our senses with
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: which we began deserts us.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: The shape of the table is no better. We are all in the habit of judging
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: as to the 'real' shapes of things, and we do this so unreflectingly that
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: we come to think we actually see the real shapes. But, in fact, as we
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: all have to learn if we try to draw, a given thing looks different
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: in shape from every different point of view. If our table is 'really'
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: rectangular, it will look, from almost all points of view, as if it had
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: two acute angles and two obtuse angles. If opposite sides are parallel,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: they will look as if they converged to a point away from the spectator;
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: if they are of equal length, they will look as if the nearer side were
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: longer. All these things are not commonly noticed in looking at a table,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: because experience has taught us to construct the 'real' shape from the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: apparent shape, and the 'real' shape is what interests us as practical
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: men. But the 'real' shape is not what we see; it is something inferred
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: from what we see. And what we see is constantly changing in shape as we
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: move about the room; so that here again the senses seem not to give us
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the truth about the table itself, but only about the appearance of the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: table.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Similar difficulties arise when we consider the sense of touch. It is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: true that the table always gives us a sensation of hardness, and we feel
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: that it resists pressure. But the sensation we obtain depends upon how
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: hard we press the table and also upon what part of the body we press
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: with; thus the various sensations due to various pressures or various
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: parts of the body cannot be supposed to reveal _directly_ any definite
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: property of the table, but at most to be _signs_ of some property which
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: perhaps _causes_ all the sensations, but is not actually apparent in any
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of them. And the same applies still more obviously to the sounds which
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: can be elicited by rapping the table.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Thus it becomes evident that the real table, if there is one, is not the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: same as what we immediately experience by sight or touch or hearing. The
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: real table, if there is one, is not _immediately_ known to us at all,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: but must be an inference from what is immediately known. Hence, two very
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: difficult questions at once arise; namely, (1) Is there a real table at
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: all? (2) If so, what sort of object can it be?
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: It will help us in considering these questions to have a few simple
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: terms of which the meaning is definite and clear. Let us give the name
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of 'sense-data' to the things that are immediately known in sensation:
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: such things as colours, sounds, smells, hardnesses, roughnesses, and
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: so on. We shall give the name 'sensation' to the experience of being
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: immediately aware of these things. Thus, whenever we see a colour,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: we have a sensation _of_ the colour, but the colour itself is a
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: sense-datum, not a sensation. The colour is that _of_ which we are
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: immediately aware, and the awareness itself is the sensation. It is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: plain that if we are to know anything about the table, it must be
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: by means of the sense-data--brown colour, oblong shape, smoothness,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: etc.--which we associate with the table; but, for the reasons which have
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: been given, we cannot say that the table is the sense-data, or even
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: that the sense-data are directly properties of the table. Thus a problem
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: arises as to the relation of the sense-data to the real table, supposing
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: there is such a thing.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: The real table, if it exists, we will call a 'physical object'. Thus
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: we have to consider the relation of sense-data to physical objects.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: The collection of all physical objects is called 'matter'. Thus our two
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: questions may be re-stated as follows: (1) Is there any such thing as
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: matter? (2) If so, what is its nature?
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: The philosopher who first brought prominently forward the reasons
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: for regarding the immediate objects of our senses as not existing
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: independently of us was Bishop Berkeley (1685-1753). His _Three
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous, in Opposition to Sceptics and
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Atheists_, undertake to prove that there is no such thing as matter at
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: all, and that the world consists of nothing but minds and their ideas.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Hylas has hitherto believed in matter, but he is no match for Philonous,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: who mercilessly drives him into contradictions and paradoxes, and makes
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: his own denial of matter seem, in the end, as if it were almost common
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: sense. The arguments employed are of very different value: some are
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: important and sound, others are confused or quibbling. But Berkeley
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: retains the merit of having shown that the existence of matter is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: capable of being denied without absurdity, and that if there are any
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: things that exist independently of us they cannot be the immediate
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: objects of our sensations.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: There are two different questions involved when we ask whether matter
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: exists, and it is important to keep them clear. We commonly mean by
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: 'matter' something which is opposed to 'mind', something which we think
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of as occupying space and as radically incapable of any sort of thought
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: or consciousness. It is chiefly in this sense that Berkeley denies
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: matter; that is to say, he does not deny that the sense-data which we
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: commonly take as signs of the existence of the table are really signs
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of the existence of _something_ independent of us, but he does deny
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: that this something is non-mental, that it is neither mind nor ideas
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: entertained by some mind. He admits that there must be something which
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: continues to exist when we go out of the room or shut our eyes, and that
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: what we call seeing the table does really give us reason for believing
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: in something which persists even when we are not seeing it. But he
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: thinks that this something cannot be radically different in nature from
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: what we see, and cannot be independent of seeing altogether, though it
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: must be independent of _our_ seeing. He is thus led to regard the 'real'
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: table as an idea in the mind of God. Such an idea has the required
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: permanence and independence of ourselves, without being--as matter would
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: otherwise be--something quite unknowable, in the sense that we can only
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: infer it, and can never be directly and immediately aware of it.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Other philosophers since Berkeley have also held that, although the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: table does not depend for its existence upon being seen by me, it does
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: depend upon being seen (or otherwise apprehended in sensation) by
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: _some_ mind--not necessarily the mind of God, but more often the whole
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: collective mind of the universe. This they hold, as Berkeley does,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: chiefly because they think there can be nothing real--or at any rate
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: nothing known to be real except minds and their thoughts and feelings.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: We might state the argument by which they support their view in some
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: such way as this: 'Whatever can be thought of is an idea in the mind of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the person thinking of it; therefore nothing can be thought of except
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: ideas in minds; therefore anything else is inconceivable, and what is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: inconceivable cannot exist.'
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Such an argument, in my opinion, is fallacious; and of course those who
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: advance it do not put it so shortly or so crudely. But whether valid or
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: not, the argument has been very widely advanced in one form or another;
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and very many philosophers, perhaps a majority, have held that there is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: nothing real except minds and their ideas. Such philosophers are called
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: 'idealists'. When they come to explaining matter, they either say, like
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Berkeley, that matter is really nothing but a collection of ideas,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: or they say, like Leibniz (1646-1716), that what appears as matter is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: really a collection of more or less rudimentary minds.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: But these philosophers, though they deny matter as opposed to mind,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: nevertheless, in another sense, admit matter. It will be remembered that
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: we asked two questions; namely, (1) Is there a real table at all? (2) If
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: so, what sort of object can it be? Now both Berkeley and Leibniz admit
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: that there is a real table, but Berkeley says it is certain ideas in the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: mind of God, and Leibniz says it is a colony of souls. Thus both of them
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: answer our first question in the affirmative, and only diverge from the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: views of ordinary mortals in their answer to our second question. In
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: fact, almost all philosophers seem to be agreed that there is a real
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: table: they almost all agree that, however much our sense-data--colour,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: shape, smoothness, etc.--may depend upon us, yet their occurrence is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: a sign of something existing independently of us, something differing,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: perhaps, completely from our sense-data, and yet to be regarded as
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: causing those sense-data whenever we are in a suitable relation to the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: real table.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Now obviously this point in which the philosophers are agreed--the view
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: that there _is_ a real table, whatever its nature may be--is vitally
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: important, and it will be worth while to consider what reasons there are
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: for accepting this view before we go on to the further question as
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to the nature of the real table. Our next chapter, therefore, will be
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: concerned with the reasons for supposing that there is a real table at
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: all.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Before we go farther it will be well to consider for a moment what it
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is that we have discovered so far. It has appeared that, if we take any
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: common object of the sort that is supposed to be known by the senses,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: what the senses _immediately_ tell us is not the truth about the object
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: as it is apart from us, but only the truth about certain sense-data
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: which, so far as we can see, depend upon the relations between us and
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the object. Thus what we directly see and feel is merely 'appearance',
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: which we believe to be a sign of some 'reality' behind. But if the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: reality is not what appears, have we any means of knowing whether there
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is any reality at all? And if so, have we any means of finding out what
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: it is like?
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Such questions are bewildering, and it is difficult to know that even
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the strangest hypotheses may not be true. Thus our familiar table,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: which has roused but the slightest thoughts in us hitherto, has become a
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: problem full of surprising possibilities. The one thing we know about it
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is that it is not what it seems. Beyond this modest result, so far, we
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: have the most complete liberty of conjecture. Leibniz tells us it is a
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: community of souls: Berkeley tells us it is an idea in the mind of God;
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: sober science, scarcely less wonderful, tells us it is a vast collection
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of electric charges in violent motion.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Among these surprising possibilities, doubt suggests that perhaps there
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is no table at all. Philosophy, if it cannot _answer_ so many questions
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: as we could wish, has at least the power of _asking_ questions which
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: increase the interest of the world, and show the strangeness and wonder
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: lying just below the surface even in the commonest things of daily life.

text: CHAPTER II. THE EXISTENCE OF MATTER
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: In this chapter we have to ask ourselves whether, in any sense at all,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: there is such a thing as matter. Is there a table which has a certain
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: intrinsic nature, and continues to exist when I am not looking, or is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the table merely a product of my imagination, a dream-table in a very
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: prolonged dream? This question is of the greatest importance. For if
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: we cannot be sure of the independent existence of objects, we cannot
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: be sure of the independent existence of other people's bodies, and
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: therefore still less of other people's minds, since we have no grounds
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: for believing in their minds except such as are derived from observing
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: their bodies. Thus if we cannot be sure of the independent existence of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: objects, we shall be left alone in a desert--it may be that the whole
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: outer world is nothing but a dream, and that we alone exist. This is an
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: uncomfortable possibility; but although it cannot be strictly proved to
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: be false, there is not the slightest reason to suppose that it is true.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: In this chapter we have to see why this is the case.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Before we embark upon doubtful matters, let us try to find some more
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: or less fixed point from which to start. Although we are doubting the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: physical existence of the table, we are not doubting the existence
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of the sense-data which made us think there was a table; we are not
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: doubting that, while we look, a certain colour and shape appear to us,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and while we press, a certain sensation of hardness is experienced by
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: us. All this, which is psychological, we are not calling in question.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: In fact, whatever else may be doubtful, some at least of our immediate
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: experiences seem absolutely certain.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Descartes (1596-1650), the founder of modern philosophy, invented a
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: method which may still be used with profit--the method of systematic
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: doubt. He determined that he would believe nothing which he did not see
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: quite clearly and distinctly to be true. Whatever he could bring himself
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to doubt, he would doubt, until he saw reason for not doubting it.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: By applying this method he gradually became convinced that the only
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: existence of which he could be _quite_ certain was his own. He imagined
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: a deceitful demon, who presented unreal things to his senses in a
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: perpetual phantasmagoria; it might be very improbable that such a demon
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: existed, but still it was possible, and therefore doubt concerning
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: things perceived by the senses was possible.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: But doubt concerning his own existence was not possible, for if he did
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: not exist, no demon could deceive him. If he doubted, he must exist; if
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: he had any experiences whatever, he must exist. Thus his own existence
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: was an absolute certainty to him. 'I think, therefore I am,' he said
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: (_Cogito, ergo sum_); and on the basis of this certainty he set to work
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to build up again the world of knowledge which his doubt had laid in
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: ruins. By inventing the method of doubt, and by showing that subjective
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: things are the most certain, Descartes performed a great service to
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: philosophy, and one which makes him still useful to all students of the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: subject.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: But some care is needed in using Descartes' argument. 'I think,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: therefore I am' says rather more than is strictly certain. It might seem
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: as though we were quite sure of being the same person to-day as we were
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: yesterday, and this is no doubt true in some sense. But the real Self is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: as hard to arrive at as the real table, and does not seem to have that
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: absolute, convincing certainty that belongs to particular experiences.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: When I look at my table and see a certain brown colour, what is quite
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: certain at once is not '_I_ am seeing a brown colour', but rather,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: 'a brown colour is being seen'. This of course involves something (or
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: somebody) which (or who) sees the brown colour; but it does not of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: itself involve that more or less permanent person whom we call 'I'. So
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: far as immediate certainty goes, it might be that the something which
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: sees the brown colour is quite momentary, and not the same as the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: something which has some different experience the next moment.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Thus it is our particular thoughts and feelings that have primitive
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: certainty. And this applies to dreams and hallucinations as well as to
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: normal perceptions: when we dream or see a ghost, we certainly do have
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the sensations we think we have, but for various reasons it is held that
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: no physical object corresponds to these sensations. Thus the certainty
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of our knowledge of our own experiences does not have to be limited in
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: any way to allow for exceptional cases. Here, therefore, we have, for
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: what it is worth, a solid basis from which to begin our pursuit of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: knowledge.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: The problem we have to consider is this: Granted that we are certain of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: our own sense-data, have we any reason for regarding them as signs of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the existence of something else, which we can call the physical object?
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: When we have enumerated all the sense-data which we should naturally
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: regard as connected with the table, have we said all there is to say
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: about the table, or is there still something else--something not a
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: sense-datum, something which persists when we go out of the room? Common
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: sense unhesitatingly answers that there is. What can be bought and sold
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and pushed about and have a cloth laid on it, and so on, cannot be
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: a _mere_ collection of sense-data. If the cloth completely hides the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: table, we shall derive no sense-data from the table, and therefore, if
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the table were merely sense-data, it would have ceased to exist, and
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the cloth would be suspended in empty air, resting, by a miracle, in
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the place where the table formerly was. This seems plainly absurd; but
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: whoever wishes to become a philosopher must learn not to be frightened
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: by absurdities.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: One great reason why it is felt that we must secure a physical object
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: in addition to the sense-data, is that we want the same object for
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: different people. When ten people are sitting round a dinner-table,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: it seems preposterous to maintain that they are not seeing the same
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: tablecloth, the same knives and forks and spoons and glasses. But the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: sense-data are private to each separate person; what is immediately
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: present to the sight of one is not immediately present to the sight of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: another: they all see things from slightly different points of view, and
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: therefore see them slightly differently. Thus, if there are to be public
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: neutral objects, which can be in some sense known to many different
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: people, there must be something over and above the private and
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: particular sense-data which appear to various people. What reason, then,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: have we for believing that there are such public neutral objects?
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: The first answer that naturally occurs to one is that, although
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: different people may see the table slightly differently, still they all
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: see more or less similar things when they look at the table, and
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the variations in what they see follow the laws of perspective and
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: reflection of light, so that it is easy to arrive at a permanent object
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: underlying all the different people's sense-data. I bought my table from
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the former occupant of my room; I could not buy _his_ sense-data,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: which died when he went away, but I could and did buy the confident
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: expectation of more or less similar sense-data. Thus it is the fact that
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: different people have similar sense-data, and that one person in a given
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: place at different times has similar sense-data, which makes us suppose
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: that over and above the sense-data there is a permanent public object
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: which underlies or causes the sense-data of various people at various
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: times.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Now in so far as the above considerations depend upon supposing that
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: there are other people besides ourselves, they beg the very question at
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: issue. Other people are represented to me by certain sense-data, such as
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the sight of them or the sound of their voices, and if I had no
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: reason to believe that there were physical objects independent of my
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: sense-data, I should have no reason to believe that other people exist
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: except as part of my dream. Thus, when we are trying to show that there
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: must be objects independent of our own sense-data, we cannot appeal to
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the testimony of other people, since this testimony itself consists of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: sense-data, and does not reveal other people's experiences unless our
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: own sense-data are signs of things existing independently of us. We must
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: therefore, if possible, find, in our own purely private experiences,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: characteristics which show, or tend to show, that there are in the world
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: things other than ourselves and our private experiences.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: In one sense it must be admitted that we can never prove the existence
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of things other than ourselves and our experiences. No logical absurdity
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: results from the hypothesis that the world consists of myself and my
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: thoughts and feelings and sensations, and that everything else is mere
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: fancy. In dreams a very complicated world may seem to be present, and
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: yet on waking we find it was a delusion; that is to say, we find that
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the sense-data in the dream do not appear to have corresponded with such
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: physical objects as we should naturally infer from our sense-data. (It
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is true that, when the physical world is assumed, it is possible to
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: find physical causes for the sense-data in dreams: a door banging, for
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: instance, may cause us to dream of a naval engagement. But although, in
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: this case, there is a physical cause for the sense-data, there is not a
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: physical object corresponding to the sense-data in the way in which an
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: actual naval battle would correspond.) There is no logical impossibility
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: in the supposition that the whole of life is a dream, in which we
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: ourselves create all the objects that come before us. But although this
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is not logically impossible, there is no reason whatever to suppose that
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: it is true; and it is, in fact, a less simple hypothesis, viewed as a
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: means of accounting for the facts of our own life, than the common-sense
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: hypothesis that there really are objects independent of us, whose action
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: on us causes our sensations.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: The way in which simplicity comes in from supposing that there really
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: are physical objects is easily seen. If the cat appears at one moment in
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: one part of the room, and at another in another part, it is natural
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to suppose that it has moved from the one to the other, passing over
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: a series of intermediate positions. But if it is merely a set of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: sense-data, it cannot have ever been in any place where I did not see
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: it; thus we shall have to suppose that it did not exist at all while I
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: was not looking, but suddenly sprang into being in a new place. If
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the cat exists whether I see it or not, we can understand from our own
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: experience how it gets hungry between one meal and the next; but if
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: it does not exist when I am not seeing it, it seems odd that appetite
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: should grow during non-existence as fast as during existence. And if the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: cat consists only of sense-data, it cannot be hungry, since no hunger
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: but my own can be a sense-datum to me. Thus the behaviour of the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: sense-data which represent the cat to me, though it seems quite natural
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: when regarded as an expression of hunger, becomes utterly inexplicable
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: when regarded as mere movements and changes of patches of colour, which
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: are as incapable of hunger as a triangle is of playing football.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: But the difficulty in the case of the cat is nothing compared to the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: difficulty in the case of human beings. When human beings speak--that
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is, when we hear certain noises which we associate with ideas, and
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: simultaneously see certain motions of lips and expressions of face--it
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is very difficult to suppose that what we hear is not the expression
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of a thought, as we know it would be if we emitted the same sounds. Of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: course similar things happen in dreams, where we are mistaken as to the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: existence of other people. But dreams are more or less suggested by what
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: we call waking life, and are capable of being more or less accounted for
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: on scientific principles if we assume that there really is a physical
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: world. Thus every principle of simplicity urges us to adopt the natural
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: view, that there really are objects other than ourselves and our
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: sense-data which have an existence not dependent upon our perceiving
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: them.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Of course it is not by argument that we originally come by our belief in
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: an independent external world. We find this belief ready in ourselves as
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: soon as we begin to reflect: it is what may be called an _instinctive_
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: belief. We should never have been led to question this belief but for
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the fact that, at any rate in the case of sight, it seems as if the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: sense-datum itself were instinctively believed to be the independent
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: object, whereas argument shows that the object cannot be identical
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: with the sense-datum. This discovery, however--which is not at all
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: paradoxical in the case of taste and smell and sound, and only slightly
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: so in the case of touch--leaves undiminished our instinctive belief that
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: there _are_ objects _corresponding_ to our sense-data. Since this belief
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: does not lead to any difficulties, but on the contrary tends to simplify
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and systematize our account of our experiences, there seems no good
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: reason for rejecting it. We may therefore admit--though with a slight
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: doubt derived from dreams--that the external world does really exist,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and is not wholly dependent for its existence upon our continuing to
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: perceive it.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: The argument which has led us to this conclusion is doubtless less
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: strong than we could wish, but it is typical of many philosophical
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: arguments, and it is therefore worth while to consider briefly its
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: general character and validity. All knowledge, we find, must be built
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: up upon our instinctive beliefs, and if these are rejected, nothing
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is left. But among our instinctive beliefs some are much stronger than
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: others, while many have, by habit and association, become entangled with
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: other beliefs, not really instinctive, but falsely supposed to be part
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of what is believed instinctively.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Philosophy should show us the hierarchy of our instinctive beliefs,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: beginning with those we hold most strongly, and presenting each as much
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: isolated and as free from irrelevant additions as possible. It should
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: take care to show that, in the form in which they are finally set forth,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: our instinctive beliefs do not clash, but form a harmonious system.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: There can never be any reason for rejecting one instinctive belief
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: except that it clashes with others; thus, if they are found to
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: harmonize, the whole system becomes worthy of acceptance.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: It is of course _possible_ that all or any of our beliefs may be
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: mistaken, and therefore all ought to be held with at least some slight
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: element of doubt. But we cannot have _reason_ to reject a belief except
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: on the ground of some other belief. Hence, by organizing our instinctive
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: beliefs and their consequences, by considering which among them is most
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: possible, if necessary, to modify or abandon, we can arrive, on the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: basis of accepting as our sole data what we instinctively believe, at an
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: orderly systematic organization of our knowledge, in which, though the

title: The Problems of Philosophy

text: interrelation of the parts and by the critical scrutiny which has
title: The Problems of Philosophy

title: The Problems of Philosophy

text: rightly or wrongly, believe that philosophy can do much more than
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: this--that it can give us knowledge, not otherwise attainable,
title: The Problems of Philosophy

text: concerning the universe as a whole, and concerning the nature of
