text: CHAPTER III. THE NATURE OF MATTER
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: In the preceding chapter we agreed, though without being able to
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: find demonstrative reasons, that it is rational to believe that our
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: sense-data--for example, those which we regard as associated with my
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: table--are really signs of the existence of something independent of us
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and our perceptions. That is to say, over and above the sensations of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: colour, hardness, noise, and so on, which make up the appearance of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the table to me, I assume that there is something else, of which these
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: things are appearances. The colour ceases to exist if I shut my eyes,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the sensation of hardness ceases to exist if I remove my arm from
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: contact with the table, the sound ceases to exist if I cease to rap the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: table with my knuckles. But I do not believe that when all these things
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: cease the table ceases. On the contrary, I believe that it is because
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the table exists continuously that all these sense-data will reappear
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: when I open my eyes, replace my arm, and begin again to rap with my
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: knuckles. The question we have to consider in this chapter is: What
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is the nature of this real table, which persists independently of my
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: perception of it?
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: To this question physical science gives an answer, somewhat incomplete
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: it is true, and in part still very hypothetical, but yet deserving of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: respect so far as it goes. Physical science, more or less unconsciously,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: has drifted into the view that all natural phenomena ought to be reduced
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to motions. Light and heat and sound are all due to wave-motions, which
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: travel from the body emitting them to the person who sees light or feels
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: heat or hears sound. That which has the wave-motion is either aether or
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: 'gross matter', but in either case is what the philosopher would call
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: matter. The only properties which science assigns to it are position in
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: space, and the power of motion according to the laws of motion. Science
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: does not deny that it _may_ have other properties; but if so, such other
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: properties are not useful to the man of science, and in no way assist
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: him in explaining the phenomena.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: It is sometimes said that 'light _is_ a form of wave-motion', but this
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is misleading, for the light which we immediately see, which we know
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: directly by means of our senses, is _not_ a form of wave-motion, but
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: something quite different--something which we all know if we are not
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: blind, though we cannot describe it so as to convey our knowledge to a
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: man who is blind. A wave-motion, on the contrary, could quite well be
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: described to a blind man, since he can acquire a knowledge of space by
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the sense of touch; and he can experience a wave-motion by a sea voyage
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: almost as well as we can. But this, which a blind man can understand, is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: not what we mean by _light_: we mean by _light_ just that which a blind
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: man can never understand, and which we can never describe to him.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Now this something, which all of us who are not blind know, is not,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: according to science, really to be found in the outer world: it is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: something caused by the action of certain waves upon the eyes and nerves
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and brain of the person who sees the light. When it is said that light
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: _is_ waves, what is really meant is that waves are the physical cause of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: our sensations of light. But light itself, the thing which seeing people
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: experience and blind people do not, is not supposed by science to form
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: any part of the world that is independent of us and our senses. And very
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: similar remarks would apply to other kinds of sensations.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: It is not only colours and sounds and so on that are absent from the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: scientific world of matter, but also _space_ as we get it through sight
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: or touch. It is essential to science that its matter should be in _a_
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: space, but the space in which it is cannot be exactly the space we see
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: or feel. To begin with, space as we see it is not the same as space as
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: we get it by the sense of touch; it is only by experience in infancy
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: that we learn how to touch things we see, or how to get a sight of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: things which we feel touching us. But the space of science is neutral as
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: between touch and sight; thus it cannot be either the space of touch or
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the space of sight.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Again, different people see the same object as of different shapes,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: according to their point of view. A circular coin, for example, though
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: we should always _judge_ it to be circular, will _look_ oval unless we
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: are straight in front of it. When we judge that it _is_ circular, we are
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: judging that it has a real shape which is not its apparent shape, but
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: belongs to it intrinsically apart from its appearance. But this real
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: shape, which is what concerns science, must be in a real space, not
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the same as anybody's _apparent_ space. The real space is public, the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: apparent space is private to the percipient. In different people's
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: _private_ spaces the same object seems to have different shapes; thus
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the real space, in which it has its real shape, must be different from
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the private spaces. The space of science, therefore, though _connected_
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: with the spaces we see and feel, is not identical with them, and the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: manner of its connexion requires investigation.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: We agreed provisionally that physical objects cannot be quite like
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: our sense-data, but may be regarded as _causing_ our sensations.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: These physical objects are in the space of science, which we may call
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: 'physical' space. It is important to notice that, if our sensations
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: are to be caused by physical objects, there must be a physical space
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: containing these objects and our sense-organs and nerves and brain. We
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: get a sensation of touch from an object when we are in contact with it;
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: that is to say, when some part of our body occupies a place in physical
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: space quite close to the space occupied by the object. We see an object
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: (roughly speaking) when no opaque body is between the object and our
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: eyes in physical space. Similarly, we only hear or smell or taste an
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: object when we are sufficiently near to it, or when it touches the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: tongue, or has some suitable position in physical space relatively to
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: our body. We cannot begin to state what different sensations we shall
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: derive from a given object under different circumstances unless we
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: regard the object and our body as both in one physical space, for it is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: mainly the relative positions of the object and our body that determine
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: what sensations we shall derive from the object.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Now our sense-data are situated in our private spaces, either the space
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of sight or the space of touch or such vaguer spaces as other senses
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: may give us. If, as science and common sense assume, there is one public
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: all-embracing physical space in which physical objects are, the relative
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: positions of physical objects in physical space must more or less
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: correspond to the relative positions of sense-data in our private
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: spaces. There is no difficulty in supposing this to be the case. If we
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: see on a road one house nearer to us than another, our other senses will
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: bear out the view that it is nearer; for example, it will be reached
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: sooner if we walk along the road. Other people will agree that the house
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: which looks nearer to us is nearer; the ordnance map will take the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: same view; and thus everything points to a spatial relation between the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: houses corresponding to the relation between the sense-data which we see
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: when we look at the houses. Thus we may assume that there is a physical
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: space in which physical objects have spatial relations corresponding to
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: those which the corresponding sense-data have in our private spaces. It
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is this physical space which is dealt with in geometry and assumed in
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: physics and astronomy.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Assuming that there is physical space, and that it does thus correspond
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to private spaces, what can we know about it? We can know _only_ what is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: required in order to secure the correspondence. That is to say, we can
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: know nothing of what it is like in itself, but we can know the sort
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of arrangement of physical objects which results from their spatial
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: relations. We can know, for example, that the earth and moon and sun
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: are in one straight line during an eclipse, though we cannot know what
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: a physical straight line is in itself, as we know the look of a straight
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: line in our visual space. Thus we come to know much more about the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: _relations_ of distances in physical space than about the distances
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: themselves; we may know that one distance is greater than another, or
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: that it is along the same straight line as the other, but we cannot have
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: that immediate acquaintance with physical distances that we have with
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: distances in our private spaces, or with colours or sounds or other
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: sense-data. We can know all those things about physical space which a
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: man born blind might know through other people about the space of sight;
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: but the kind of things which a man born blind could never know about the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: space of sight we also cannot know about physical space. We can know the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: properties of the relations required to preserve the correspondence with
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: sense-data, but we cannot know the nature of the terms between which the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: relations hold.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: With regard to time, our _feeling_ of duration or of the lapse of time
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is notoriously an unsafe guide as to the time that has elapsed by the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: clock. Times when we are bored or suffering pain pass slowly, times when
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: we are agreeably occupied pass quickly, and times when we are sleeping
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: pass almost as if they did not exist. Thus, in so far as time is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: constituted by duration, there is the same necessity for distinguishing
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: a public and a private time as there was in the case of space. But in so
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: far as time consists in an _order_ of before and after, there is no need
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to make such a distinction; the time-order which events seem to have is,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: so far as we can see, the same as the time-order which they do have. At
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: any rate no reason can be given for supposing that the two orders are
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: not the same. The same is usually true of space: if a regiment of men
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: are marching along a road, the shape of the regiment will look different
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: from different points of view, but the men will appear arranged in the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: same order from all points of view. Hence we regard the order as true
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: also in physical space, whereas the shape is only supposed to correspond
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to the physical space so far as is required for the preservation of the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: order.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: In saying that the time-order which events seem to have is the same as
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the time-order which they really have, it is necessary to guard against
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: a possible misunderstanding. It must not be supposed that the various
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: states of different physical objects have the same time-order as the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: sense-data which constitute the perceptions of those objects. Considered
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: as physical objects, the thunder and lightning are simultaneous; that is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to say, the lightning is simultaneous with the disturbance of the air in
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the place where the disturbance begins, namely, where the lightning
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is. But the sense-datum which we call hearing the thunder does not take
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: place until the disturbance of the air has travelled as far as to where
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: we are. Similarly, it takes about eight minutes for the sun's light
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to reach us; thus, when we see the sun we are seeing the sun of eight
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: minutes ago. So far as our sense-data afford evidence as to the physical
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: sun they afford evidence as to the physical sun of eight minutes ago; if
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the physical sun had ceased to exist within the last eight minutes, that
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: would make no difference to the sense-data which we call 'seeing
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the sun'. This affords a fresh illustration of the necessity of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: distinguishing between sense-data and physical objects.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: What we have found as regards space is much the same as what we find
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: in relation to the correspondence of the sense-data with their
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: physical counterparts. If one object looks blue and another red, we may
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: reasonably presume that there is some corresponding difference between
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the physical objects; if two objects both look blue, we may presume a
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: corresponding similarity. But we cannot hope to be acquainted directly
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: with the quality in the physical object which makes it look blue or red.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Science tells us that this quality is a certain sort of wave-motion, and
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: this sounds familiar, because we think of wave-motions in the space we
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: see. But the wave-motions must really be in physical space, with which
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: we have no direct acquaintance; thus the real wave-motions have not that
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: familiarity which we might have supposed them to have. And what holds
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: for colours is closely similar to what holds for other sense-data. Thus
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: we find that, although the _relations_ of physical objects have all
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: sorts of knowable properties, derived from their correspondence with the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: relations of sense-data, the physical objects themselves remain unknown
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: in their intrinsic nature, so far at least as can be discovered by means
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of the senses. The question remains whether there is any other method of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: discovering the intrinsic nature of physical objects.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: The most natural, though not ultimately the most defensible, hypothesis
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to adopt in the first instance, at any rate as regards visual
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: sense-data, would be that, though physical objects cannot, for the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: reasons we have been considering, be _exactly_ like sense-data, yet they
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: may be more or less like. According to this view, physical objects will,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: for example, really have colours, and we might, by good luck, see an
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: object as of the colour it really is. The colour which an object seems
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to have at any given moment will in general be very similar, though
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: not quite the same, from many different points of view; we might thus
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: suppose the 'real' colour to be a sort of medium colour, intermediate
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: between the various shades which appear from the different points of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: view.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Such a theory is perhaps not capable of being definitely refuted, but
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: it can be shown to be groundless. To begin with, it is plain that the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: colour we see depends only upon the nature of the light-waves that
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: strike the eye, and is therefore modified by the medium intervening
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: between us and the object, as well as by the manner in which light is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: reflected from the object in the direction of the eye. The intervening
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: air alters colours unless it is perfectly clear, and any strong
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: reflection will alter them completely. Thus the colour we see is a
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: result of the ray as it reaches the eye, and not simply a property of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the object from which the ray comes. Hence, also, provided certain waves
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: reach the eye, we shall see a certain colour, whether the object from
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: which the waves start has any colour or not. Thus it is quite gratuitous
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to suppose that physical objects have colours, and therefore there is no
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: justification for making such a supposition. Exactly similar arguments
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: will apply to other sense-data.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: It remains to ask whether there are any general philosophical arguments
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: enabling us to say that, if matter is real, it must be of such and such
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: a nature. As explained above, very many philosophers, perhaps most, have
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: held that whatever is real must be in some sense mental, or at any rate
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: that whatever we can know anything about must be in some sense mental.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Such philosophers are called 'idealists'. Idealists tell us that what
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: appears as matter is really something mental; namely, either (as Leibniz
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: held) more or less rudimentary minds, or (as Berkeley contended) ideas
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: in the minds which, as we should commonly say, 'perceive' the matter.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Thus idealists deny the existence of matter as something intrinsically
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: different from mind, though they do not deny that our sense-data are
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: signs of something which exists independently of our private sensations.

text: CHAPTER IV. IDEALISM
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: The word 'idealism' is used by different philosophers in somewhat
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: different senses. We shall understand by it the doctrine that whatever
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: exists, or at any rate whatever can be known to exist, must be in
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: some sense mental. This doctrine, which is very widely held among
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: philosophers, has several forms, and is advocated on several different
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: grounds. The doctrine is so widely held, and so interesting in itself,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: that even the briefest survey of philosophy must give some account of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: it.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Those who are unaccustomed to philosophical speculation may be inclined
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to dismiss such a doctrine as obviously absurd. There is no doubt that
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: common sense regards tables and chairs and the sun and moon and material
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: objects generally as something radically different from minds and the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: contents of minds, and as having an existence which might continue if
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: minds ceased. We think of matter as having existed long before there
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: were any minds, and it is hard to think of it as a mere product of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: mental activity. But whether true or false, idealism is not to be
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: dismissed as obviously absurd.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: We have seen that, even if physical objects do have an independent
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: existence, they must differ very widely from sense-data, and can only
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: have a _correspondence_ with sense-data, in the same sort of way in
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: which a catalogue has a correspondence with the things catalogued. Hence
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: common sense leaves us completely in the dark as to the true intrinsic
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: nature of physical objects, and if there were good reason to regard them
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: as mental, we could not legitimately reject this opinion merely because
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: it strikes us as strange. The truth about physical objects _must_ be
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: strange. It may be unattainable, but if any philosopher believes that
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: he has attained it, the fact that what he offers as the truth is strange
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: ought not to be made a ground of objection to his opinion.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: The grounds on which idealism is advocated are generally grounds derived
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: from the theory of knowledge, that is to say, from a discussion of the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: conditions which things must satisfy in order that we may be able to
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: know them. The first serious attempt to establish idealism on such
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: grounds was that of Bishop Berkeley. He proved first, by arguments which
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: were largely valid, that our sense-data cannot be supposed to have an
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: existence independent of us, but must be, in part at least, 'in' the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: mind, in the sense that their existence would not continue if there were
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: no seeing or hearing or touching or smelling or tasting. So far, his
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: contention was almost certainly valid, even if some of his arguments
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: were not so. But he went on to argue that sense-data were the only
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: things of whose existence our perceptions could assure us; and that
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to be known is to be 'in' a mind, and therefore to be mental. Hence he
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: concluded that nothing can ever be known except what is in some mind,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and that whatever is known without being in my mind must be in some
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: other mind.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: In order to understand his argument, it is necessary to understand his
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: use of the word 'idea'. He gives the name 'idea' to anything which
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is _immediately_ known, as, for example, sense-data are known. Thus a
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: particular colour which we see is an idea; so is a voice which we hear,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and so on. But the term is not wholly confined to sense-data. There will
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: also be things remembered or imagined, for with such things also we have
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: immediate acquaintance at the moment of remembering or imagining. All
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: such immediate data he calls 'ideas'.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: He then proceeds to consider common objects, such as a tree, for
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: instance. He shows that all we know immediately when we 'perceive' the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: tree consists of ideas in his sense of the word, and he argues that
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: there is not the slightest ground for supposing that there is anything
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: real about the tree except what is perceived. Its being, he says,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: consists in being perceived: in the Latin of the schoolmen its '_esse_'
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is '_percipi_'. He fully admits that the tree must continue to exist
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: even when we shut our eyes or when no human being is near it. But this
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: continued existence, he says, is due to the fact that God continues to
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: perceive it; the 'real' tree, which corresponds to what we called the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: physical object, consists of ideas in the mind of God, ideas more or
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: less like those we have when we see the tree, but differing in the fact
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: that they are permanent in God's mind so long as the tree continues
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to exist. All our perceptions, according to him, consist in a
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: partial participation in God's perceptions, and it is because of this
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: participation that different people see more or less the same tree. Thus
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: apart from minds and their ideas there is nothing in the world, nor is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: it possible that anything else should ever be known, since whatever is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: known is necessarily an idea.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: There are in this argument a good many fallacies which have been
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: important in the history of philosophy, and which it will be as well to
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: bring to light. In the first place, there is a confusion engendered by
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the use of the word 'idea'. We think of an idea as essentially something
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: in somebody's mind, and thus when we are told that a tree consists
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: entirely of ideas, it is natural to suppose that, if so, the tree
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: must be entirely in minds. But the notion of being 'in' the mind is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: ambiguous. We speak of bearing a person in mind, not meaning that the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: person is in our minds, but that a thought of him is in our minds. When
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: a man says that some business he had to arrange went clean out of his
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: mind, he does not mean to imply that the business itself was ever in his
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: mind, but only that a thought of the business was formerly in his mind,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: but afterwards ceased to be in his mind. And so when Berkeley says that
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the tree must be in our minds if we can know it, all that he really has
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: a right to say is that a thought of the tree must be in our minds. To
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: argue that the tree itself must be in our minds is like arguing that a
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: person whom we bear in mind is himself in our minds. This confusion
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: may seem too gross to have been really committed by any competent
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: philosopher, but various attendant circumstances rendered it possible.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: In order to see how it was possible, we must go more deeply into the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: question as to the nature of ideas.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Before taking up the general question of the nature of ideas, we must
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: disentangle two entirely separate questions which arise concerning
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: sense-data and physical objects. We saw that, for various reasons of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: detail, Berkeley was right in treating the sense-data which constitute
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: our perception of the tree as more or less subjective, in the sense that
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: they depend upon us as much as upon the tree, and would not exist if the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: tree were not being perceived. But this is an entirely different point
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: from the one by which Berkeley seeks to prove that whatever can be
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: immediately known must be in a mind. For this purpose arguments of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: detail as to the dependence of sense-data upon us are useless. It is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: necessary to prove, generally, that by being known, things are shown to
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: be mental. This is what Berkeley believes himself to have done. It
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is this question, and not our previous question as to the difference
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: between sense-data and the physical object, that must now concern us.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Taking the word 'idea' in Berkeley's sense, there are two quite distinct
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: things to be considered whenever an idea is before the mind. There is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: on the one hand the thing of which we are aware--say the colour of my
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: table--and on the other hand the actual awareness itself, the mental act
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of apprehending the thing. The mental act is undoubtedly mental, but is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: there any reason to suppose that the thing apprehended is in any sense
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: mental? Our previous arguments concerning the colour did not prove it to
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: be mental; they only proved that its existence depends upon the relation
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of our sense organs to the physical object--in our case, the table. That
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is to say, they proved that a certain colour will exist, in a certain
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: light, if a normal eye is placed at a certain point relatively to
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the table. They did not prove that the colour is in the mind of the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: percipient.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Berkeley's view, that obviously the colour must be in the mind, seems
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to depend for its plausibility upon confusing the thing apprehended
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: with the act of apprehension. Either of these might be called an 'idea';
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: probably either would have been called an idea by Berkeley. The act
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is undoubtedly in the mind; hence, when we are thinking of the act,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: we readily assent to the view that ideas must be in the mind. Then,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: forgetting that this was only true when ideas were taken as acts of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: apprehension, we transfer the proposition that 'ideas are in the mind'
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to ideas in the other sense, i.e. to the things apprehended by our acts
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of apprehension. Thus, by an unconscious equivocation, we arrive at the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: conclusion that whatever we can apprehend must be in our minds. This
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: seems to be the true analysis of Berkeley's argument, and the ultimate
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: fallacy upon which it rests.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: This question of the distinction between act and object in our
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: apprehending of things is vitally important, since our whole power of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: acquiring knowledge is bound up with it. The faculty of being acquainted
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: with things other than itself is the main characteristic of a mind.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Acquaintance with objects essentially consists in a relation between the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: mind and something other than the mind; it is this that constitutes the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: mind's power of knowing things. If we say that the things known must be
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: in the mind, we are either unduly limiting the mind's power of knowing,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: or we are uttering a mere tautology. We are uttering a mere tautology if
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: we mean by '_in_ the mind' the same as by '_before_ the mind', i.e. if
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: we mean merely being apprehended by the mind. But if we mean this, we
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: shall have to admit that what, _in this sense_, is in the mind,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: may nevertheless be not mental. Thus when we realize the nature of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: knowledge, Berkeley's argument is seen to be wrong in substance as well
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: as in form, and his grounds for supposing that 'ideas'--i.e. the objects
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: apprehended--must be mental, are found to have no validity whatever.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Hence his grounds in favour of idealism may be dismissed. It remains to
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: see whether there are any other grounds.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: It is often said, as though it were a self-evident truism, that we
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: cannot know that anything exists which we do not know. It is inferred
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: that whatever can in any way be relevant to our experience must be at
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: least capable of being known by us; whence it follows that if matter
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: were essentially something with which we could not become acquainted,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: matter would be something which we could not know to exist, and which
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: could have for us no importance whatever. It is generally also implied,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: for reasons which remain obscure, that what can have no importance for
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: us cannot be real, and that therefore matter, if it is not composed of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: minds or of mental ideas, is impossible and a mere chimaera.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: To go into this argument fully at our present stage would be impossible,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: since it raises points requiring a considerable preliminary discussion;
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: but certain reasons for rejecting the argument may be noticed at
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: once. To begin at the end: there is no reason why what cannot have any
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: _practical_ importance for us should not be real. It is true that,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: if _theoretical_ importance is included, everything real is of _some_
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: importance to us, since, as persons desirous of knowing the truth about
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the universe, we have some interest in everything that the universe
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: contains. But if this sort of interest is included, it is not the case
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: that matter has no importance for us, provided it exists even if we
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: cannot know that it exists. We can, obviously, suspect that it may
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: exist, and wonder whether it does; hence it is connected with our desire
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: for knowledge, and has the importance of either satisfying or thwarting
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: this desire.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Again, it is by no means a truism, and is in fact false, that we cannot
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: know that anything exists which we do not know. The word 'know' is here
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: used in two different senses. (1) In its first use it is applicable to
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the sort of knowledge which is opposed to error, the sense in which
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: what we know is _true_, the sense which applies to our beliefs and
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: convictions, i.e. to what are called _judgements_. In this sense of the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: word we know _that_ something is the case. This sort of knowledge may
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: be described as knowledge of _truths_. (2) In the second use of the word
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: 'know' above, the word applies to our knowledge of _things_, which we
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: may call _acquaintance_. This is the sense in which we know sense-data.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: (The distinction involved is roughly that between _savoir_ and
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: _connaitre_ in French, or between _wissen_ and _kennen_ in German.)
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Thus the statement which seemed like a truism becomes, when re-stated,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the following: 'We can never truly judge that something with which we
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: are not acquainted exists.' This is by no means a truism, but on the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: contrary a palpable falsehood. I have not the honour to be acquainted
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: with the Emperor of China, but I truly judge that he exists. It may
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: be said, of course, that I judge this because of other people's
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: acquaintance with him. This, however, would be an irrelevant retort,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: since, if the principle were true, I could not know that any one else
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is acquainted with him. But further: there is no reason why I should not
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: know of the existence of something with which nobody is acquainted. This
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: point is important, and demands elucidation.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: If I am acquainted with a thing which exists, my acquaintance gives
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: me the knowledge that it exists. But it is not true that, conversely,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: whenever I can know that a thing of a certain sort exists, I or some one
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: else must be acquainted with the thing. What happens, in cases where I
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: have true judgement without acquaintance, is that the thing is known to
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: me by _description_, and that, in virtue of some general principle, the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: existence of a thing answering to this description can be inferred
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: from the existence of something with which I am acquainted. In order
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to understand this point fully, it will be well first to deal with
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the difference between knowledge by acquaintance and knowledge by
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: description, and then to consider what knowledge of general principles,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: if any, has the same kind of certainty as our knowledge of the existence
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of our own experiences. These subjects will be dealt with in the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: following chapters.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: CHAPTER V. KNOWLEDGE BY ACQUAINTANCE AND KNOWLEDGE BY DESCRIPTION
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: In the preceding chapter we saw that there are two sorts of knowledge:
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: knowledge of things, and knowledge of truths. In this chapter we shall
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: be concerned exclusively with knowledge of things, of which in turn we
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: shall have to distinguish two kinds. Knowledge of things, when it is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of the kind we call knowledge by _acquaintance_, is essentially simpler
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: than any knowledge of truths, and logically independent of knowledge
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of truths, though it would be rash to assume that human beings ever,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: in fact, have acquaintance with things without at the same time knowing
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: some truth about them. Knowledge of things by _description_, on the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: contrary, always involves, as we shall find in the course of the present
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: chapter, some knowledge of truths as its source and ground. But first of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: all we must make clear what we mean by 'acquaintance' and what we mean
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: by 'description'.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: We shall say that we have _acquaintance_ with anything of which we are
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: directly aware, without the intermediary of any process of inference
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: or any knowledge of truths. Thus in the presence of my table I am
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: acquainted with the sense-data that make up the appearance of my
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: table--its colour, shape, hardness, smoothness, etc.; all these are
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: things of which I am immediately conscious when I am seeing and touching
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: my table. The particular shade of colour that I am seeing may have many
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: things said about it--I may say that it is brown, that it is rather
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: dark, and so on. But such statements, though they make me know truths
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: about the colour, do not make me know the colour itself any better
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: than I did before so far as concerns knowledge of the colour itself, as
