text: is to say, when we say anything about Bismarck, we should like, if we
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: could, to make the judgement which Bismarck alone can make, namely,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the judgement of which he himself is a constituent. In this we are
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: necessarily defeated, since the actual Bismarck is unknown to us. But
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: we know that there is an object B, called Bismarck, and that B was an
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: astute diplomatist. We can thus _describe_ the proposition we should
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: like to affirm, namely, 'B was an astute diplomatist', where B is the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: object which was Bismarck. If we are describing Bismarck as 'the first
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Chancellor of the German Empire', the proposition we should like to
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: affirm may be described as 'the proposition asserting, concerning the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: actual object which was the first Chancellor of the German Empire, that
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: this object was an astute diplomatist'. What enables us to communicate
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: in spite of the varying descriptions we employ is that we know there is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: a true proposition concerning the actual Bismarck, and that however we
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: may vary the description (so long as the description is correct) the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: proposition described is still the same. This proposition, which is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: described and is known to be true, is what interests us; but we are not
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: acquainted with the proposition itself, and do not know it, though we
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: know it is true.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: It will be seen that there are various stages in the removal from
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: acquaintance with particulars: there is Bismarck to people who knew him;
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Bismarck to those who only know of him through history; the man with
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the iron mask; the longest-lived of men. These are progressively further
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: removed from acquaintance with particulars; the first comes as near to
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: acquaintance as is possible in regard to another person; in the second,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: we shall still be said to know 'who Bismarck was'; in the third, we do
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: not know who was the man with the iron mask, though we can know many
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: propositions about him which are not logically deducible from the fact
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: that he wore an iron mask; in the fourth, finally, we know nothing
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: beyond what is logically deducible from the definition of the man. There
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is a similar hierarchy in the region of universals. Many universals,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: like many particulars, are only known to us by description. But here,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: as in the case of particulars, knowledge concerning what is known by
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: description is ultimately reducible to knowledge concerning what is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: known by acquaintance.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: The fundamental principle in the analysis of propositions containing
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: descriptions is this: _Every proposition which we can understand must be
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: composed wholly of constituents with which we are acquainted_.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: We shall not at this stage attempt to answer all the objections which
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: may be urged against this fundamental principle. For the present, we
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: shall merely point out that, in some way or other, it must be possible
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to meet these objections, for it is scarcely conceivable that we can
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: make a judgement or entertain a supposition without knowing what it is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: that we are judging or supposing about. We must attach _some_ meaning
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to the words we use, if we are to speak significantly and not utter mere
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: noise; and the meaning we attach to our words must be something with
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: which we are acquainted. Thus when, for example, we make a statement
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: about Julius Caesar, it is plain that Julius Caesar himself is not
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: before our minds, since we are not acquainted with him. We have in mind
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: some description of Julius Caesar: 'the man who was assassinated on the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Ides of March', 'the founder of the Roman Empire', or, perhaps, merely
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: 'the man whose name was _Julius Caesar_'. (In this last description,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: _Julius Caesar_ is a noise or shape with which we are acquainted.)
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Thus our statement does not mean quite what it seems to mean, but means
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: something involving, instead of Julius Caesar, some description of him
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: which is composed wholly of particulars and universals with which we are
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: acquainted.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: The chief importance of knowledge by description is that it enables us
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to pass beyond the limits of our private experience. In spite of the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: fact that we can only know truths which are wholly composed of terms
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: which we have experienced in acquaintance, we can yet have knowledge by
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: description of things which we have never experienced. In view of the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: very narrow range of our immediate experience, this result is vital, and
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: until it is understood, much of our knowledge must remain mysterious and
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: therefore doubtful.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: CHAPTER VI. ON INDUCTION
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: In almost all our previous discussions we have been concerned in
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the attempt to get clear as to our data in the way of knowledge of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: existence. What things are there in the universe whose existence is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: known to us owing to our being acquainted with them? So far, our answer
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: has been that we are acquainted with our sense-data, and, probably,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: with ourselves. These we know to exist. And past sense-data which
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: are remembered are known to have existed in the past. This knowledge
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: supplies our data.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: But if we are to be able to draw inferences from these data--if we are
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to know of the existence of matter, of other people, of the past before
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: our individual memory begins, or of the future, we must know general
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: principles of some kind by means of which such inferences can be drawn.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: It must be known to us that the existence of some one sort of thing, A,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is a sign of the existence of some other sort of thing, B, either at
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the same time as A or at some earlier or later time, as, for example,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: thunder is a sign of the earlier existence of lightning. If this were
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: not known to us, we could never extend our knowledge beyond the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: sphere of our private experience; and this sphere, as we have seen, is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: exceedingly limited. The question we have now to consider is whether
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: such an extension is possible, and if so, how it is effected.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Let us take as an illustration a matter about which none of us, in fact,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: feel the slightest doubt. We are all convinced that the sun will rise
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to-morrow. Why? Is this belief a mere blind outcome of past experience,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: or can it be justified as a reasonable belief? It is not easy to find
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: a test by which to judge whether a belief of this kind is reasonable or
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: not, but we can at least ascertain what sort of general beliefs would
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: suffice, if true, to justify the judgement that the sun will rise
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to-morrow, and the many other similar judgements upon which our actions
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: are based.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: It is obvious that if we are asked why we believe that the sun will rise
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to-morrow, we shall naturally answer 'Because it always has risen every
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: day'. We have a firm belief that it will rise in the future, because it
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: has risen in the past. If we are challenged as to why we believe that
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: it will continue to rise as heretofore, we may appeal to the laws of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: motion: the earth, we shall say, is a freely rotating body, and such
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: bodies do not cease to rotate unless something interferes from outside,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and there is nothing outside to interfere with the earth between now and
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to-morrow. Of course it might be doubted whether we are quite certain
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: that there is nothing outside to interfere, but this is not the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: interesting doubt. The interesting doubt is as to whether the laws
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of motion will remain in operation until to-morrow. If this doubt is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: raised, we find ourselves in the same position as when the doubt about
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the sunrise was first raised.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: The _only_ reason for believing that the laws of motion will remain in
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: operation is that they have operated hitherto, so far as our knowledge
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of the past enables us to judge. It is true that we have a greater body
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of evidence from the past in favour of the laws of motion than we have
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: in favour of the sunrise, because the sunrise is merely a particular
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: case of fulfilment of the laws of motion, and there are countless other
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: particular cases. But the real question is: Do _any_ number of cases
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of a law being fulfilled in the past afford evidence that it will be
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: fulfilled in the future? If not, it becomes plain that we have no ground
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: whatever for expecting the sun to rise to-morrow, or for expecting the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: bread we shall eat at our next meal not to poison us, or for any of the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: other scarcely conscious expectations that control our daily lives. It
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is to be observed that all such expectations are only _probable_; thus
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: we have not to seek for a proof that they _must_ be fulfilled, but
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: only for some reason in favour of the view that they are _likely_ to be
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: fulfilled.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Now in dealing with this question we must, to begin with, make an
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: important distinction, without which we should soon become involved
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: in hopeless confusions. Experience has shown us that, hitherto, the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: frequent repetition of some uniform succession or coexistence has been a
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: _cause_ of our expecting the same succession or coexistence on the next
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: occasion. Food that has a certain appearance generally has a certain
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: taste, and it is a severe shock to our expectations when the familiar
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: appearance is found to be associated with an unusual taste. Things which
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: we see become associated, by habit, with certain tactile sensations
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: which we expect if we touch them; one of the horrors of a ghost (in
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: many ghost-stories) is that it fails to give us any sensations of touch.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Uneducated people who go abroad for the first time are so surprised as
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to be incredulous when they find their native language not understood.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: And this kind of association is not confined to men; in animals also it
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is very strong. A horse which has been often driven along a certain
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: road resists the attempt to drive him in a different direction. Domestic
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: animals expect food when they see the person who usually feeds them. We
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: know that all these rather crude expectations of uniformity are liable
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to be misleading. The man who has fed the chicken every day throughout
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: its life at last wrings its neck instead, showing that more refined
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: views as to the uniformity of nature would have been useful to the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: chicken.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: But in spite of the misleadingness of such expectations, they
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: nevertheless exist. The mere fact that something has happened a certain
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: number of times causes animals and men to expect that it will happen
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: again. Thus our instincts certainly cause us to believe that the sun
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: will rise to-morrow, but we may be in no better a position than the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: chicken which unexpectedly has its neck wrung. We have therefore to
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: distinguish the fact that past uniformities _cause_ expectations as to
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the future, from the question whether there is any reasonable ground for
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: giving weight to such expectations after the question of their validity
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: has been raised.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: The problem we have to discuss is whether there is any reason for
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: believing in what is called 'the uniformity of nature'. The belief in
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the uniformity of nature is the belief that everything that has happened
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: or will happen is an instance of some general law to which there are no
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: exceptions. The crude expectations which we have been considering are
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: all subject to exceptions, and therefore liable to disappoint those who
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: entertain them. But science habitually assumes, at least as a working
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: hypothesis, that general rules which have exceptions can be replaced by
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: general rules which have no exceptions. 'Unsupported bodies in air fall'
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is a general rule to which balloons and aeroplanes are exceptions. But
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the laws of motion and the law of gravitation, which account for the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: fact that most bodies fall, also account for the fact that balloons and
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: aeroplanes can rise; thus the laws of motion and the law of gravitation
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: are not subject to these exceptions.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: The belief that the sun will rise to-morrow might be falsified if the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: earth came suddenly into contact with a large body which destroyed its
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: rotation; but the laws of motion and the law of gravitation would not
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: be infringed by such an event. The business of science is to find
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: uniformities, such as the laws of motion and the law of gravitation,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to which, so far as our experience extends, there are no exceptions.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: In this search science has been remarkably successful, and it may be
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: conceded that such uniformities have held hitherto. This brings us back
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to the question: Have we any reason, assuming that they have always held
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: in the past, to suppose that they will hold in the future?
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: It has been argued that we have reason to know that the future will
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: resemble the past, because what was the future has constantly become the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: past, and has always been found to resemble the past, so that we really
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: have experience of the future, namely of times which were formerly
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: future, which we may call past futures. But such an argument really begs
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the very question at issue. We have experience of past futures, but not
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of future futures, and the question is: Will future futures resemble
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: past futures? This question is not to be answered by an argument which
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: starts from past futures alone. We have therefore still to seek for some
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: principle which shall enable us to know that the future will follow the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: same laws as the past.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: The reference to the future in this question is not essential. The same
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: question arises when we apply the laws that work in our experience to
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: past things of which we have no experience--as, for example, in geology,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: or in theories as to the origin of the Solar System. The question we
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: really have to ask is: 'When two things have been found to be often
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: associated, and no instance is known of the one occurring without the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: other, does the occurrence of one of the two, in a fresh instance, give
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: any good ground for expecting the other?' On our answer to this question
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: must depend the validity of the whole of our expectations as to the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: future, the whole of the results obtained by induction, and in fact
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: practically all the beliefs upon which our daily life is based.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: It must be conceded, to begin with, that the fact that two things have
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: been found often together and never apart does not, by itself, suffice
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to _prove_ demonstratively that they will be found together in the next
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: case we examine. The most we can hope is that the oftener things are
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: found together, the more probable it becomes that they will be found
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: together another time, and that, if they have been found together often
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: enough, the probability will amount _almost_ to certainty. It can
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: never quite reach certainty, because we know that in spite of frequent
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: repetitions there sometimes is a failure at the last, as in the case
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of the chicken whose neck is wrung. Thus probability is all we ought to
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: seek.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: It might be urged, as against the view we are advocating, that we
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: know all natural phenomena to be subject to the reign of law, and that
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: sometimes, on the basis of observation, we can see that only one law
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: can possibly fit the facts of the case. Now to this view there are two
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: answers. The first is that, even if _some_ law which has no exceptions
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: applies to our case, we can never, in practice, be sure that we have
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: discovered that law and not one to which there are exceptions. The
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: second is that the reign of law would seem to be itself only probable,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and that our belief that it will hold in the future, or in unexamined
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: cases in the past, is itself based upon the very principle we are
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: examining.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: The principle we are examining may be called the _principle of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: induction_, and its two parts may be stated as follows:
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: (a) When a thing of a certain sort A has been found to be associated
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: with a thing of a certain other sort B, and has never been found
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: dissociated from a thing of the sort B, the greater the number of cases
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: in which A and B have been associated, the greater is the probability
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: that they will be associated in a fresh case in which one of them is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: known to be present;
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: (b) Under the same circumstances, a sufficient number of cases of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: association will make the probability of a fresh association nearly a
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: certainty, and will make it approach certainty without limit.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: As just stated, the principle applies only to the verification of our
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: expectation in a single fresh instance. But we want also to know that
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: there is a probability in favour of the general law that things of the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: sort A are _always_ associated with things of the sort B, provided a
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: sufficient number of cases of association are known, and no cases of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: failure of association are known. The probability of the general law is

title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: B. There may be other data, which _might_ be taken into account, which
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: would gravely alter the probability. For example, a man who had seen a
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

author: Russell, Bertrand

title: The Problems of Philosophy

title: The Problems of Philosophy

author: Russell, Bertrand

author: Russell, Bertrand

title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: The inductive principle, however, is equally incapable of being _proved_
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: by an appeal to experience. Experience might conceivably confirm
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the inductive principle as regards the cases that have been already
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: examined; but as regards unexamined cases, it is the inductive principle
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: alone that can justify any inference from what has been examined to what
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: has not been examined. All arguments which, on the basis of experience,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: argue as to the future or the unexperienced parts of the past or
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: present, assume the inductive principle; hence we can never use
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: experience to prove the inductive principle without begging the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: question. Thus we must either accept the inductive principle on the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: ground of its intrinsic evidence, or forgo all justification of our
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: expectations about the future. If the principle is unsound, we have no
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: reason to expect the sun to rise to-morrow, to expect bread to be more
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: nourishing than a stone, or to expect that if we throw ourselves off

author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the roof we shall fall. When we see what looks like our best friend

author: Russell, Bertrand

text: approaching us, we shall have no reason to suppose that his body is not
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: inhabited by the mind of our worst enemy or of some total stranger. All
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: our conduct is based upon associations which have worked in the past,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and which we therefore regard as likely to work in the future; and this
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: likelihood is dependent for its validity upon the inductive principle.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: The general principles of science, such as the belief in the reign
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of law, and the belief that every event must have a cause, are as
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: completely dependent upon the inductive principle as are the beliefs of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: daily life All such general principles are believed because mankind have
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: found innumerable instances of their truth and no instances of their
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: falsehood. But this affords no evidence for their truth in the future,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: unless the inductive principle is assumed.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Thus all knowledge which, on a basis of experience tells us something
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: about what is not experienced, is based upon a belief which experience

author: Russell, Bertrand

text: can neither confirm nor confute, yet which, at least in its more

author: Russell, Bertrand

title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of the facts of experience. The existence and justification of such

author: Russell, Bertrand

author: Russell, Bertrand

text: CHAPTER VII. ON OUR KNOWLEDGE OF GENERAL PRINCIPLES
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: We saw in the preceding chapter that the principle of induction, while
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: necessary to the validity of all arguments based on experience,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is itself not capable of being proved by experience, and yet is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: unhesitatingly believed by every one, at least in all its concrete
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: applications. In these characteristics the principle of induction does
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: not stand alone. There are a number of other principles which cannot be
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: proved or disproved by experience, but are used in arguments which start
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: from what is experienced.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Some of these principles have even greater evidence than the principle
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of induction, and the knowledge of them has the same degree of certainty
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: as the knowledge of the existence of sense-data. They constitute the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: means of drawing inferences from what is given in sensation; and if what
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: we infer is to be true, it is just as necessary that our principles
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of inference should be true as it is that our data should be true. The
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: principles of inference are apt to be overlooked because of their
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: very obviousness--the assumption involved is assented to without our
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: realizing that it is an assumption. But it is very important to realize
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the use of principles of inference, if a correct theory of knowledge
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is to be obtained; for our knowledge of them raises interesting and
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: difficult questions.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: In all our knowledge of general principles, what actually happens
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is that first of all we realize some particular application of the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: principle, and then we realize that the particularity is irrelevant, and
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: that there is a generality which may equally truly be affirmed. This is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of course familiar in such matters as teaching arithmetic: 'two and
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: two are four' is first learnt in the case of some particular pair of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: couples, and then in some other particular case, and so on, until at
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: last it becomes possible to see that it is true of any pair of couples.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: The same thing happens with logical principles. Suppose two men are
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: discussing what day of the month it is. One of them says, 'At least you
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: will admit that _if_ yesterday was the 15th to-day must be the 16th.'
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: 'Yes', says the other, 'I admit that.' 'And you know', the first
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: continues, 'that yesterday was the 15th, because you dined with Jones,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and your diary will tell you that was on the 15th.' 'Yes', says the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: second; 'therefore to-day _is_ the 16th.'
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Now such an argument is not hard to follow; and if it is granted that
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: its premisses are true in fact, no one will deny that the conclusion
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: must also be true. But it depends for its truth upon an instance of a
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: general logical principle. The logical principle is as follows: 'Suppose
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: it known that _if_ this is true, then that is true. Suppose it also
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: known that this _is_ true, then it follows that that is true.' When it
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is the case that if this is true, that is true, we shall say that this
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: 'implies' that, and that that 'follows from' this. Thus our principle
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: states that if this implies that, and this is true, then that is true.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: In other words, 'anything implied by a true proposition is true', or
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: 'whatever follows from a true proposition is true'.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: This principle is really involved--at least, concrete instances of it
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: are involved--in all demonstrations. Whenever one thing which we believe
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is used to prove something else, which we consequently believe, this
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: principle is relevant. If any one asks: 'Why should I accept the results
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of valid arguments based on true premisses?' we can only answer by
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: appealing to our principle. In fact, the truth of the principle is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: impossible to doubt, and its obviousness is so great that at first sight
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: it seems almost trivial. Such principles, however, are not trivial to
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the philosopher, for they show that we may have indubitable knowledge
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: which is in no way derived from objects of sense.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: The above principle is merely one of a certain number of self-evident
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: logical principles. Some at least of these principles must be granted
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: before any argument or proof becomes possible. When some of them have
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: been granted, others can be proved, though these others, so long as they
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: are simple, are just as obvious as the principles taken for granted. For
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: no very good reason, three of these principles have been singled out by
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: tradition under the name of 'Laws of Thought'.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: They are as follows:
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: (1) _The law of identity_: 'Whatever is, is.'
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: (2) _The law of contradiction_: 'Nothing can both be and not be.'
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: (3) _The law of excluded middle_: 'Everything must either be or not be.'
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: These three laws are samples of self-evident logical principles, but
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: are not really more fundamental or more self-evident than various other
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: similar principles: for instance, the one we considered just now, which
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: states that what follows from a true premiss is true. The name 'laws of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: thought' is also misleading, for what is important is not the fact that
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: we think in accordance with these laws, but the fact that things behave
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: in accordance with them; in other words, the fact that when we think in
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: accordance with them we think _truly_. But this is a large question, to
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: which we must return at a later stage.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: In addition to the logical principles which enable us to prove from
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: a given premiss that something is _certainly_ true, there are other
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: logical principles which enable us to prove, from a given premiss,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: that there is a greater or less probability that something is true. An
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: example of such principles--perhaps the most important example is the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: inductive principle, which we considered in the preceding chapter.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: One of the great historic controversies in philosophy is the controversy
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: between the two schools called respectively 'empiricists' and
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: 'rationalists'. The empiricists--who are best represented by the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: British philosophers, Locke, Berkeley, and Hume--maintained that all
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: our knowledge is derived from experience; the rationalists--who are
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: represented by the Continental philosophers of the seventeenth century,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: especially Descartes and Leibniz--maintained that, in addition to what
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: we know by experience, there are certain 'innate ideas' and 'innate
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: principles', which we know independently of experience. It has now
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: become possible to decide with some confidence as to the truth or
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: falsehood of these opposing schools. It must be admitted, for the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: reasons already stated, that logical principles are known to us, and
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: cannot be themselves proved by experience, since all proof presupposes
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: them. In this, therefore, which was the most important point of the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: controversy, the rationalists were in the right.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: On the other hand, even that part of our knowledge which is _logically_
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: independent of experience (in the sense that experience cannot prove
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: it) is yet elicited and caused by experience. It is on occasion of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: particular experiences that we become aware of the general laws which
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: their connexions exemplify. It would certainly be absurd to suppose that
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: there are innate principles in the sense that babies are born with a
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: knowledge of everything which men know and which cannot be deduced from
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: what is experienced. For this reason, the word 'innate' would not now be
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: employed to describe our knowledge of logical principles. The phrase
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: '_a priori_' is less objectionable, and is more usual in modern writers.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Thus, while admitting that all knowledge is elicited and caused by
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: experience, we shall nevertheless hold that some knowledge is _a
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: priori_, in the sense that the experience which makes us think of it
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: does not suffice to prove it, but merely so directs our attention that
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: we see its truth without requiring any proof from experience.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: There is another point of great importance, in which the empiricists
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: were in the right as against the rationalists. Nothing can be known to
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: _exist_ except by the help of experience. That is to say, if we wish to
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: prove that something of which we have no direct experience exists, we
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: must have among our premisses the existence of one or more things of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: which we have direct experience. Our belief that the Emperor of China
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: exists, for example, rests upon testimony, and testimony consists,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: in the last analysis, of sense-data seen or heard in reading or being
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: spoken to. Rationalists believed that, from general consideration as
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to what must be, they could deduce the existence of this or that in the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: actual world. In this belief they seem to have been mistaken. All the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: knowledge that we can acquire _a priori_ concerning existence seems
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to be hypothetical: it tells us that if one thing exists, another must
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: exist, or, more generally, that if one proposition is true, another must
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: be true. This is exemplified by the principles we have already dealt
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: with, such as '_if_ this is true, and this implies that, then that is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: true', or '_if_ this and that have been repeatedly found connected, they
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: will probably be connected in the next instance in which one of them is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: found'. Thus the scope and power of _a priori_ principles is strictly
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: limited. All knowledge that something exists must be in part dependent
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: on experience. When anything is known immediately, its existence is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: known by experience alone; when anything is proved to exist, without
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: being known immediately, both experience and _a priori_ principles must
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: be required in the proof. Knowledge is called _empirical_ when it rests
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: wholly or partly upon experience. Thus all knowledge which asserts
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: existence is empirical, and the only _a priori_ knowledge concerning
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: existence is hypothetical, giving connexions among things that exist or
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: may exist, but not giving actual existence.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: _A priori_ knowledge is not all of the logical kind we have been
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: hitherto considering. Perhaps the most important example of non-logical
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: _a priori_ knowledge is knowledge as to ethical value. I am not speaking
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of judgements as to what is useful or as to what is virtuous, for such
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: judgements do require empirical premisses; I am speaking of judgements
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: as to the intrinsic desirability of things. If something is useful, it
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: must be useful because it secures some end; the end must, if we have
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: gone far enough, be valuable on its own account, and not merely because
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: it is useful for some further end. Thus all judgements as to what is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: useful depend upon judgements as to what has value on its own account.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: We judge, for example, that happiness is more desirable than misery,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: knowledge than ignorance, goodwill than hatred, and so on. Such
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: judgements must, in part at least, be immediate and _a priori_. Like our
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: previous _a priori_ judgements, they may be elicited by experience, and
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: indeed they must be; for it seems not possible to judge whether anything
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is intrinsically valuable unless we have experienced something of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the same kind. But it is fairly obvious that they cannot be proved by
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: experience; for the fact that a thing exists or does not exist cannot
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: prove either that it is good that it should exist or that it is bad. The
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: pursuit of this subject belongs to ethics, where the impossibility of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: deducing what ought to be from what is has to be established. In the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: present connexion, it is only important to realize that knowledge as to
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: what is intrinsically of value is _a priori_ in the same sense in
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: which logic is _a priori_, namely in the sense that the truth of such
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: knowledge can be neither proved nor disproved by experience.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: All pure mathematics is _a priori_, like logic. This was strenuously
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: denied by the empirical philosophers, who maintained that experience was
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: as much the source of our knowledge of arithmetic as of our knowledge of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: geography. They maintained that by the repeated experience of seeing two
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: things and two other things, and finding that altogether they made four
title: The Problems of Philosophy

text: we think of them or not. Two physical objects and two other physical
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: objects must make four physical objects, even if physical objects cannot
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: be experienced. To assert this is certainly within the scope of what
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: we mean when we state that two and two are four. Its truth is just as
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: indubitable as the truth of the assertion that two phenomena and two
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: other phenomena make four phenomena. Thus Kant's solution unduly limits
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the scope of _a priori_ propositions, in addition to failing in the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: attempt at explaining their certainty.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Apart from the special doctrines advocated by Kant, it is very common
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: among philosophers to regard what is _a priori_ as in some sense mental,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: as concerned rather with the way we must think than with any fact of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the outer world. We noted in the preceding chapter the three principles
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: commonly called 'laws of thought'. The view which led to their being so
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: named is a natural one, but there are strong reasons for thinking
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: that it is erroneous. Let us take as an illustration the law of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: contradiction. This is commonly stated in the form 'Nothing can both be
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and not be', which is intended to express the fact that nothing can at
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: once have and not have a given quality. Thus, for example, if a tree
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is a beech it cannot also be not a beech; if my table is rectangular it
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: cannot also be not rectangular, and so on.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Now what makes it natural to call this principle a law of _thought_
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is that it is by thought rather than by outward observation that we
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: persuade ourselves of its necessary truth. When we have seen that a tree
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is a beech, we do not need to look again in order to ascertain whether
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: it is also not a beech; thought alone makes us know that this is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: impossible. But the conclusion that the law of contradiction is a law
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of _thought_ is nevertheless erroneous. What we believe, when we believe
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the law of contradiction, is not that the mind is so made that it must
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: believe the law of contradiction. _This_ belief is a subsequent result
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of psychological reflection, which presupposes the belief in the law of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: contradiction. The belief in the law of contradiction is a belief about
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: things, not only about thoughts. It is not, e.g., the belief that if we
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: _think_ a certain tree is a beech, we cannot at the same time _think_
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: that it is not a beech; it is the belief that if the tree _is_ a
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: beech, it cannot at the same time _be_ not a beech. Thus the law of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: contradiction is about things, and not merely about thoughts; and
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: although belief in the law of contradiction is a thought, the law of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: contradiction itself is not a thought, but a fact concerning the things
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: in the world. If this, which we believe when we believe the law of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: contradiction, were not true of the things in the world, the fact
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: that we were compelled to _think_ it true would not save the law of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: contradiction from being false; and this shows that the law is not a law
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of _thought_.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: A similar argument applies to any other _a priori_ judgement. When we
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: judge that two and two are four, we are not making a judgement about our
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: thoughts, but about all actual or possible couples. The fact that our
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: minds are so constituted as to believe that two and two are four, though
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: it is true, is emphatically not what we assert when we assert that two
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and two are four. And no fact about the constitution of our minds could
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: make it _true_ that two and two are four. Thus our _a priori_ knowledge,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: if it is not erroneous, is not merely knowledge about the constitution
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of our minds, but is applicable to whatever the world may contain, both
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: what is mental and what is non-mental.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: The fact seems to be that all our _a priori_ knowledge is concerned with
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: entities which do not, properly speaking, _exist_, either in the mental
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: or in the physical world. These entities are such as can be named by
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: parts of speech which are not substantives; they are such entities as
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: qualities and relations. Suppose, for instance, that I am in my room. I
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: exist, and my room exists; but does 'in' exist? Yet obviously the word
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: 'in' has a meaning; it denotes a relation which holds between me and my
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: room. This relation is something, although we cannot say that it exists
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: _in the same sense_ in which I and my room exist. The relation 'in' is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: something which we can think about and understand, for, if we could not
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: understand it, we could not understand the sentence 'I am in my room'.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Many philosophers, following Kant, have maintained that relations are
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the work of the mind, that things in themselves have no relations,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: but that the mind brings them together in one act of thought and thus
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: produces the relations which it judges them to have.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: This view, however, seems open to objections similar to those which we
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: urged before against Kant. It seems plain that it is not thought which
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: produces the truth of the proposition 'I am in my room'. It may be true
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: that an earwig is in my room, even if neither I nor the earwig nor any
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: one else is aware of this truth; for this truth concerns only the earwig
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and the room, and does not depend upon anything else. Thus relations, as
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: we shall see more fully in the next chapter, must be placed in a world
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: which is neither mental nor physical. This world is of great importance
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to philosophy, and in particular to the problems of _a priori_
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: knowledge. In the next chapter we shall proceed to develop its nature
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and its bearing upon the questions with which we have been dealing.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: CHAPTER IX. THE WORLD OF UNIVERSALS
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: At the end of the preceding chapter we saw that such entities as
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: relations appear to have a being which is in some way different from
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: that of physical objects, and also different from that of minds and from
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: that of sense-data. In the present chapter we have to consider what is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the nature of this kind of being, and also what objects there are that
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: have this kind of being. We will begin with the latter question.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: The problem with which we are now concerned is a very old one, since it
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: was brought into philosophy by Plato. Plato's 'theory of ideas' is an
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: attempt to solve this very problem, and in my opinion it is one of the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: most successful attempts hitherto made. The theory to be advocated in
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: what follows is largely Plato's, with merely such modifications as time
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: has shown to be necessary.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: The way the problem arose for Plato was more or less as follows. Let
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: us consider, say, such a notion as _justice_. If we ask ourselves what
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: justice is, it is natural to proceed by considering this, that, and the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: other just act, with a view to discovering what they have in common.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: They must all, in some sense, partake of a common nature, which will be
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: found in whatever is just and in nothing else. This common nature, in
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: virtue of which they are all just, will be justice itself, the pure
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: essence the admixture of which with facts of ordinary life produces the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: multiplicity of just acts. Similarly with any other word which may be
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: applicable to common facts, such as 'whiteness' for example. The word
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: will be applicable to a number of particular things because they all
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: participate in a common nature or essence. This pure essence is what
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Plato calls an 'idea' or 'form'. (It must not be supposed that 'ideas',
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: in his sense, exist in minds, though they may be apprehended by minds.)
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: The 'idea' _justice_ is not identical with anything that is just: it is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: something other than particular things, which particular things partake
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of. Not being particular, it cannot itself exist in the world of sense.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Moreover it is not fleeting or changeable like the things of sense: it
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is eternally itself, immutable and indestructible.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Thus Plato is led to a supra-sensible world, more real than the common
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: world of sense, the unchangeable world of ideas, which alone gives to
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the world of sense whatever pale reflection of reality may belong to it.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: The truly real world, for Plato, is the world of ideas; for whatever
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: we may attempt to say about things in the world of sense, we can only
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: succeed in saying that they participate in such and such ideas, which,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: therefore, constitute all their character. Hence it is easy to pass
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: on into a mysticism. We may hope, in a mystic illumination, to see the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: ideas as we see objects of sense; and we may imagine that the ideas
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: exist in heaven. These mystical developments are very natural, but the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: basis of the theory is in logic, and it is as based in logic that we
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: have to consider it.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: The word 'idea' has acquired, in the course of time, many associations
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: which are quite misleading when applied to Plato's 'ideas'. We shall
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: therefore use the word 'universal' instead of the word 'idea', to
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: describe what Plato meant. The essence of the sort of entity that Plato
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: meant is that it is opposed to the particular things that are given in
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: sensation. We speak of whatever is given in sensation, or is of the same
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: nature as things given in sensation, as a _particular_; by opposition
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to this, a _universal_ will be anything which may be shared by many
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: particulars, and has those characteristics which, as we saw, distinguish
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: justice and whiteness from just acts and white things.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: When we examine common words, we find that, broadly speaking, proper
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: names stand for particulars, while other substantives, adjectives,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: prepositions, and verbs stand for universals. Pronouns stand for
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: particulars, but are ambiguous: it is only by the context or the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: circumstances that we know what particulars they stand for. The word
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: 'now' stands for a particular, namely the present moment; but like
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: pronouns, it stands for an ambiguous particular, because the present is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: always changing.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: It will be seen that no sentence can be made up without at least one
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: word which denotes a universal. The nearest approach would be some such
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: statement as 'I like this'. But even here the word 'like' denotes
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: a universal, for I may like other things, and other people may like
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: things. Thus all truths involve universals, and all knowledge of truths
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: involves acquaintance with universals.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Seeing that nearly all the words to be found in the dictionary stand
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand
