text: for universals, it is strange that hardly anybody except students of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: philosophy ever realizes that there are such entities as universals. We
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: do not naturally dwell upon those words in a sentence which do not stand
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: for particulars; and if we are forced to dwell upon a word which stands
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: for a universal, we naturally think of it as standing for some one of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the particulars that come under the universal. When, for example, we
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: hear the sentence, 'Charles I's head was cut off', we may naturally
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: enough think of Charles I, of Charles I's head, and of the operation
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of cutting off _his_ head, which are all particulars; but we do not
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: naturally dwell upon what is meant by the word 'head' or the word
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: 'cut', which is a universal: We feel such words to be incomplete and
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: insubstantial; they seem to demand a context before anything can be
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: done with them. Hence we succeed in avoiding all notice of universals as
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: such, until the study of philosophy forces them upon our attention.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Even among philosophers, we may say, broadly, that only those universals
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: which are named by adjectives or substantives have been much or often
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: recognized, while those named by verbs and prepositions have been
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: usually overlooked. This omission has had a very great effect upon
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: philosophy; it is hardly too much to say that most metaphysics, since
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Spinoza, has been largely determined by it. The way this has occurred
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is, in outline, as follows: Speaking generally, adjectives and common
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: nouns express qualities or properties of single things, whereas
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: prepositions and verbs tend to express relations between two or more
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: things. Thus the neglect of prepositions and verbs led to the belief
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: that every proposition can be regarded as attributing a property to a
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: single thing, rather than as expressing a relation between two or more
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: things. Hence it was supposed that, ultimately, there can be no such
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: entities as relations between things. Hence either there can be only
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: one thing in the universe, or, if there are many things, they cannot
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: possibly interact in any way, since any interaction would be a relation,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and relations are impossible.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: The first of these views, advocated by Spinoza and held in our own day
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: by Bradley and many other philosophers, is called _monism_; the second,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: advocated by Leibniz but not very common nowadays, is called _monadism_,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: because each of the isolated things is called a _monad_. Both these
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: opposing philosophies, interesting as they are, result, in my opinion,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: from an undue attention to one sort of universals, namely the sort
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: represented by adjectives and substantives rather than by verbs and
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: prepositions.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: As a matter of fact, if any one were anxious to deny altogether that
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: there are such things as universals, we should find that we cannot
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: strictly prove that there are such entities as _qualities_, i.e. the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: universals represented by adjectives and substantives, whereas we
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: can prove that there must be _relations_, i.e. the sort of universals
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: generally represented by verbs and prepositions. Let us take in
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: illustration the universal _whiteness_. If we believe that there is such
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: a universal, we shall say that things are white because they have the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: quality of whiteness. This view, however, was strenuously denied by
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Berkeley and Hume, who have been followed in this by later empiricists.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: The form which their denial took was to deny that there are such things
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: as 'abstract ideas '. When we want to think of whiteness, they said, we
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: form an image of some particular white thing, and reason concerning this
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: particular, taking care not to deduce anything concerning it which we
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: cannot see to be equally true of any other white thing. As an account of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: our actual mental processes, this is no doubt largely true. In geometry,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: for example, when we wish to prove something about all triangles, we
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: draw a particular triangle and reason about it, taking care not to use
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: any characteristic which it does not share with other triangles. The
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: beginner, in order to avoid error, often finds it useful to draw several
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: triangles, as unlike each other as possible, in order to make sure that
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: his reasoning is equally applicable to all of them. But a difficulty
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: emerges as soon as we ask ourselves how we know that a thing is white
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: or a triangle. If we wish to avoid the universals _whiteness_ and
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: _triangularity_, we shall choose some particular patch of white or some
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: particular triangle, and say that anything is white or a triangle if it
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: has the right sort of resemblance to our chosen particular. But then the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: resemblance required will have to be a universal. Since there are many
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: white things, the resemblance must hold between many pairs of particular
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: white things; and this is the characteristic of a universal. It will be
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: useless to say that there is a different resemblance for each pair, for
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: then we shall have to say that these resemblances resemble each other,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and thus at last we shall be forced to admit resemblance as a universal.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: The relation of resemblance, therefore, must be a true universal. And
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: having been forced to admit this universal, we find that it is no longer
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: worth while to invent difficult and unplausible theories to avoid the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: admission of such universals as whiteness and triangularity.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Berkeley and Hume failed to perceive this refutation of their rejection
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of 'abstract ideas', because, like their adversaries, they only thought
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of _qualities_, and altogether ignored _relations_ as universals. We
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: have therefore here another respect in which the rationalists appear to
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: have been in the right as against the empiricists, although, owing to
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the neglect or denial of relations, the deductions made by rationalists
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: were, if anything, more apt to be mistaken than those made by
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: empiricists.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Having now seen that there must be such entities as universals, the next
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: point to be proved is that their being is not merely mental. By this is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: meant that whatever being belongs to them is independent of their being
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: thought of or in any way apprehended by minds. We have already touched
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: on this subject at the end of the preceding chapter, but we must now
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: consider more fully what sort of being it is that belongs to universals.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Consider such a proposition as 'Edinburgh is north of London'. Here we
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: have a relation between two places, and it seems plain that the relation
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: subsists independently of our knowledge of it. When we come to know that
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Edinburgh is north of London, we come to know something which has to
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: do only with Edinburgh and London: we do not cause the truth of the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: proposition by coming to know it, on the contrary we merely apprehend a
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: fact which was there before we knew it. The part of the earth's surface
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: where Edinburgh stands would be north of the part where London stands,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: even if there were no human being to know about north and south, and
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: even if there were no minds at all in the universe. This is, of course,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: denied by many philosophers, either for Berkeley's reasons or for
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Kant's. But we have already considered these reasons, and decided that
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: they are inadequate. We may therefore now assume it to be true that
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: nothing mental is presupposed in the fact that Edinburgh is north of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: London. But this fact involves the relation 'north of', which is a
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: universal; and it would be impossible for the whole fact to involve
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: nothing mental if the relation 'north of', which is a constituent part
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of the fact, did involve anything mental. Hence we must admit that the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: relation, like the terms it relates, is not dependent upon thought, but
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: belongs to the independent world which thought apprehends but does not
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: create.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: This conclusion, however, is met by the difficulty that the relation
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: 'north of' does not seem to _exist_ in the same sense in which Edinburgh
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and London exist. If we ask 'Where and when does this relation exist?'
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the answer must be 'Nowhere and nowhen'. There is no place or time where
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: we can find the relation 'north of'. It does not exist in Edinburgh any
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: more than in London, for it relates the two and is neutral as between
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: them. Nor can we say that it exists at any particular time. Now
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: everything that can be apprehended by the senses or by introspection
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: exists at some particular time. Hence the relation 'north of' is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: radically different from such things. It is neither in space nor in
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: time, neither material nor mental; yet it is something.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: It is largely the very peculiar kind of being that belongs to universals
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: which has led many people to suppose that they are really mental. We
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: can think _of_ a universal, and our thinking then exists in a perfectly
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: ordinary sense, like any other mental act. Suppose, for example, that
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: we are thinking of whiteness. Then _in one sense_ it may be said that
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: whiteness is 'in our mind'. We have here the same ambiguity as we noted
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: in discussing Berkeley in Chapter IV. In the strict sense, it is not
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: whiteness that is in our mind, but the act of thinking of whiteness. The
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: connected ambiguity in the word 'idea', which we noted at the same time,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: also causes confusion here. In one sense of this word, namely the sense
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: in which it denotes the _object_ of an act of thought, whiteness is an
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: 'idea'. Hence, if the ambiguity is not guarded against, we may come to
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: think that whiteness is an 'idea' in the other sense, i.e. an act of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: thought; and thus we come to think that whiteness is mental. But in so
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: thinking, we rob it of its essential quality of universality. One man's
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: act of thought is necessarily a different thing from another man's; one
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: man's act of thought at one time is necessarily a different thing from
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the same man's act of thought at another time. Hence, if whiteness were
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the thought as opposed to its object, no two different men could think
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of it, and no one man could think of it twice. That which many different
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: thoughts of whiteness have in common is their _object_, and this object
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is different from all of them. Thus universals are not thoughts, though
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: when known they are the objects of thoughts.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: We shall find it convenient only to speak of things _existing_ when they
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: are in time, that is to say, when we can point to some time at which
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: they exist (not excluding the possibility of their existing at all
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: times). Thus thoughts and feelings, minds and physical objects exist.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: But universals do not exist in this sense; we shall say that they
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: _subsist_ or _have being_, where 'being' is opposed to 'existence'
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: as being timeless. The world of universals, therefore, may also be
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: described as the world of being. The world of being is unchangeable,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: rigid, exact, delightful to the mathematician, the logician, the builder
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of metaphysical systems, and all who love perfection more than life. The
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: world of existence is fleeting, vague, without sharp boundaries,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: without any clear plan or arrangement, but it contains all thoughts and
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: feelings, all the data of sense, and all physical objects, everything
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: that can do either good or harm, everything that makes any difference to
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the value of life and the world. According to our temperaments, we shall
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: prefer the contemplation of the one or of the other. The one we do not
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: prefer will probably seem to us a pale shadow of the one we prefer, and
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: hardly worthy to be regarded as in any sense real. But the truth is that
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: both have the same claim on our impartial attention, both are real,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and both are important to the metaphysician. Indeed no sooner have we
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: distinguished the two worlds than it becomes necessary to consider their
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: relations.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: But first of all we must examine our knowledge of universals. This
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: consideration will occupy us in the following chapter, where we shall
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: find that it solves the problem of _a priori_ knowledge, from which we
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: were first led to consider universals.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: CHAPTER X. ON OUR KNOWLEDGE OF UNIVERSALS
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: In regard to one man's knowledge at a given time, universals, like
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: particulars, may be divided into those known by acquaintance, those
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: known only by description, and those not known either by acquaintance or
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: by description.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Let us consider first the knowledge of universals by acquaintance. It is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: obvious, to begin with, that we are acquainted with such universals as
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: white, red, black, sweet, sour, loud, hard, etc., i.e. with qualities
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: which are exemplified in sense-data. When we see a white patch, we are
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: acquainted, in the first instance, with the particular patch; but by
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: seeing many white patches, we easily learn to abstract the whiteness
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: which they all have in common, and in learning to do this we are
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: learning to be acquainted with whiteness. A similar process will make us
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: acquainted with any other universal of the same sort. Universals of this
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: sort may be called 'sensible qualities'. They can be apprehended with
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: less effort of abstraction than any others, and they seem less removed
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: from particulars than other universals are.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: We come next to relations. The easiest relations to apprehend are those
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: which hold between the different parts of a single complex sense-datum.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: For example, I can see at a glance the whole of the page on which I
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: am writing; thus the whole page is included in one sense-datum. But I
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: perceive that some parts of the page are to the left of other parts,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and some parts are above other parts. The process of abstraction in this
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: case seems to proceed somewhat as follows: I see successively a number
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of sense-data in which one part is to the left of another; I perceive,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: as in the case of different white patches, that all these sense-data
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: have something in common, and by abstraction I find that what they have
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: in common is a certain relation between their parts, namely the relation
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: which I call 'being to the left of'. In this way I become acquainted
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: with the universal relation.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: In like manner I become aware of the relation of before and after in
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: time. Suppose I hear a chime of bells: when the last bell of the chime
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: sounds, I can retain the whole chime before my mind, and I can perceive
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: that the earlier bells came before the later ones. Also in memory I
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: perceive that what I am remembering came before the present time. From
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: either of these sources I can abstract the universal relation of before
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and after, just as I abstracted the universal relation 'being to the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: left of'. Thus time-relations, like space-relations, are among those
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: with which we are acquainted.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Another relation with which we become acquainted in much the same way is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: resemblance. If I see simultaneously two shades of green, I can see
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: that they resemble each other; if I also see a shade of red: at the same
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: time, I can see that the two greens have more resemblance to each other
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: than either has to the red. In this way I become acquainted with the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: universal _resemblance_ or _similarity_.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Between universals, as between particulars, there are relations of which
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: we may be immediately aware. We have just seen that we can perceive
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: that the resemblance between two shades of green is greater than the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: resemblance between a shade of red and a shade of green. Here we are
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: dealing with a relation, namely 'greater than', between two relations.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Our knowledge of such relations, though it requires more power of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: abstraction than is required for perceiving the qualities of sense-data,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: appears to be equally immediate, and (at least in some cases) equally
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: indubitable. Thus there is immediate knowledge concerning universals as
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: well as concerning sense-data.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Returning now to the problem of _a priori_ knowledge, which we left
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: unsolved when we began the consideration of universals, we find
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: ourselves in a position to deal with it in a much more satisfactory
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: manner than was possible before. Let us revert to the proposition 'two
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and two are four'. It is fairly obvious, in view of what has been said,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: that this proposition states a relation between the universal 'two' and
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the universal 'four'. This suggests a proposition which we shall
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: now endeavour to establish: namely, _All _a priori_ knowledge deals
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: exclusively with the relations of universals_. This proposition is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of great importance, and goes a long way towards solving our previous
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: difficulties concerning _a priori_ knowledge.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: The only case in which it might seem, at first sight, as if our
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: proposition were untrue, is the case in which an _a priori_ proposition
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: states that _all_ of one class of particulars belong to some other
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: class, or (what comes to the same thing) that _all_ particulars having
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: some one property also have some other. In this case it might seem
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: as though we were dealing with the particulars that have the property
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: rather than with the property. The proposition 'two and two are four' is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: really a case in point, for this may be stated in the form 'any two
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and any other two are four', or 'any collection formed of two twos is a
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: collection of four'. If we can show that such statements as this really
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: deal only with universals, our proposition may be regarded as proved.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: One way of discovering what a proposition deals with is to ask ourselves
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: what words we must understand--in other words, what objects we must be
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: acquainted with--in order to see what the proposition means. As soon as
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: we see what the proposition means, even if we do not yet know whether
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: it is true or false, it is evident that we must have acquaintance with
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: whatever is really dealt with by the proposition. By applying this test,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: it appears that many propositions which might seem to be concerned with
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: particulars are really concerned only with universals. In the special
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: case of 'two and two are four', even when we interpret it as meaning
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: 'any collection formed of two twos is a collection of four', it is plain
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: that we can understand the proposition, i.e. we can see what it is that
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: it asserts, as soon as we know what is meant by 'collection' and 'two'
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and 'four'. It is quite unnecessary to know all the couples in the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: world: if it were necessary, obviously we could never understand the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: proposition, since the couples are infinitely numerous and therefore
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: cannot all be known to us. Thus although our general statement _implies_
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: statements about particular couples, _as soon as we know that there are
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: such particular couples_, yet it does not itself assert or imply that
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: there are such particular couples, and thus fails to make any statement
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: whatever about any actual particular couple. The statement made is about
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: 'couple', the universal, and not about this or that couple.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Thus the statement 'two and two are four' deals exclusively with
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: universals, and therefore may be known by anybody who is acquainted
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: with the universals concerned and can perceive the relation between them
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: which the statement asserts. It must be taken as a fact, discovered
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: by reflecting upon our knowledge, that we have the power of sometimes
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: perceiving such relations between universals, and therefore of sometimes
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: knowing general _a priori_ propositions such as those of arithmetic and
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: logic. The thing that seemed mysterious, when we formerly considered
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: such knowledge, was that it seemed to anticipate and control experience.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: This, however, we can now see to have been an error. _No_ fact
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: concerning anything capable of being experienced can be known
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: independently of experience. We know _a priori_ that two things and two
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: other things together make four things, but we do _not_ know _a priori_
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: that if Brown and Jones are two, and Robinson and Smith are two, then
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Brown and Jones and Robinson and Smith are four. The reason is that this
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: proposition cannot be understood at all unless we know that there are
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: such people as Brown and Jones and Robinson and Smith, and this we can
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: only know by experience. Hence, although our general proposition is _a
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: priori_, all its applications to actual particulars involve experience
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and therefore contain an empirical element. In this way what seemed
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: mysterious in our _a priori_ knowledge is seen to have been based upon
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: an error.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: It will serve to make the point clearer if we contrast our genuine _a
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: priori_ judgement with an empirical generalization, such as 'all men are
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: mortals'. Here as before, we can _understand_ what the proposition
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: means as soon as we understand the universals involved, namely _man_ and
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: _mortal_. It is obviously unnecessary to have an individual acquaintance
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: with the whole human race in order to understand what our proposition
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: means. Thus the difference between an _a priori_ general proposition
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and an empirical generalization does not come in the _meaning_ of the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: proposition; it comes in the nature of the _evidence_ for it. In the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: empirical case, the evidence consists in the particular instances.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: We believe that all men are mortal because we know that there are
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: innumerable instances of men dying, and no instances of their living
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: beyond a certain age. We do not believe it because we see a connexion
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: between the universal _man_ and the universal _mortal_. It is true that
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: if physiology can prove, assuming the general laws that govern living
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: bodies, that no living organism can last for ever, that gives a
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: connexion between _man_ and _mortality_ which would enable us to assert
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: our proposition without appealing to the special evidence of _men_
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: dying. But that only means that our generalization has been subsumed
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: under a wider generalization, for which the evidence is still of the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: same kind, though more extensive. The progress of science is constantly
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: producing such subsumptions, and therefore giving a constantly wider
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: inductive basis for scientific generalizations. But although this gives
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: a greater _degree_ of certainty, it does not give a different _kind_:
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the ultimate ground remains inductive, i.e. derived from instances, and
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: not an _a priori_ connexion of universals such as we have in logic and
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: arithmetic.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Two opposite points are to be observed concerning _a priori_ general
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: propositions. The first is that, if many particular instances are known,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: our general proposition may be arrived at in the first instance by
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: induction, and the connexion of universals may be only subsequently
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: perceived. For example, it is known that if we draw perpendiculars
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to the sides of a triangle from the opposite angles, all three
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: perpendiculars meet in a point. It would be quite possible to be first
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: led to this proposition by actually drawing perpendiculars in many
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: cases, and finding that they always met in a point; this experience
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: might lead us to look for the general proof and find it. Such cases are
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: common in the experience of every mathematician.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: The other point is more interesting, and of more philosophical
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: importance. It is, that we may sometimes know a general proposition in
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: cases where we do not know a single instance of it. Take such a case as
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the following: We know that any two numbers can be multiplied together,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and will give a third called their _product_. We know that all pairs
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of integers the product of which is less than 100 have been actually
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: multiplied together, and the value of the product recorded in the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: multiplication table. But we also know that the number of integers is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: infinite, and that only a finite number of pairs of integers ever have
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: been or ever will be thought of by human beings. Hence it follows that
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: there are pairs of integers which never have been and never will be
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: thought of by human beings, and that all of them deal with integers the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: product of which is over 100. Hence we arrive at the proposition:
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: 'All products of two integers, which never have been and never will
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: be thought of by any human being, are over 100.' Here is a general
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: proposition of which the truth is undeniable, and yet, from the very
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: nature of the case, we can never give an instance; because any two
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: numbers we may think of are excluded by the terms of the proposition.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: This possibility, of knowledge of general propositions of which no
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: instance can be given, is often denied, because it is not perceived
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: that the knowledge of such propositions only requires a knowledge of the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: relations of universals, and does not require any knowledge of instances
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of the universals in question. Yet the knowledge of such general
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: propositions is quite vital to a great deal of what is generally
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: admitted to be known. For example, we saw, in our early chapters,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: that knowledge of physical objects, as opposed to sense-data, is only
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: obtained by an inference, and that they are not things with which we are
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: acquainted. Hence we can never know any proposition of the form 'this
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is a physical object', where 'this' is something immediately known. It
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: follows that all our knowledge concerning physical objects is such that
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: no actual instance can be given. We can give instances of the associated
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: sense-data, but we cannot give instances of the actual physical objects.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Hence our knowledge as to physical objects depends throughout upon this
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: possibility of general knowledge where no instance can be given. And the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: same applies to our knowledge of other people's minds, or of any other
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: class of things of which no instance is known to us by acquaintance.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: We may now take a survey of the sources of our knowledge, as they have
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: appeared in the course of our analysis. We have first to distinguish
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: knowledge of things and knowledge of truths. In each there are two
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: kinds, one immediate and one derivative. Our immediate knowledge of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: things, which we called _acquaintance_, consists of two sorts, according
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: as the things known are particulars or universals. Among particulars, we
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: have acquaintance with sense-data and (probably) with ourselves. Among
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: universals, there seems to be no principle by which we can decide which
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: can be known by acquaintance, but it is clear that among those that
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: can be so known are sensible qualities, relations of space and time,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: similarity, and certain abstract logical universals. Our derivative
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: knowledge of things, which we call knowledge by _description_, always
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: involves both acquaintance with something and knowledge of truths. Our
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: immediate knowledge of _truths_ may be called _intuitive_ knowledge,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and the truths so known may be called _self-evident_ truths. Among such
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: truths are included those which merely state what is given in sense, and
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: also certain abstract logical and arithmetical principles, and (though
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: with less certainty) some ethical propositions. Our _derivative_
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: knowledge of truths consists of everything that we can deduce from
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: self-evident truths by the use of self-evident principles of deduction.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: If the above account is correct, all our knowledge of truths depends
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: upon our intuitive knowledge. It therefore becomes important to consider
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the nature and scope of intuitive knowledge, in much the same way as,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: at an earlier stage, we considered the nature and scope of knowledge by
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: acquaintance. But knowledge of truths raises a further problem, which
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: does not arise in regard to knowledge of things, namely the problem of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: _error_. Some of our beliefs turn out to be erroneous, and therefore
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: it becomes necessary to consider how, if at all, we can distinguish
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: knowledge from error. This problem does not arise with regard
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to knowledge by acquaintance, for, whatever may be the object of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: acquaintance, even in dreams and hallucinations, there is no error
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: involved so long as we do not go beyond the immediate object: error can
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: only arise when we regard the immediate object, i.e. the sense-datum,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: as the mark of some physical object. Thus the problems connected
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: with knowledge of truths are more difficult than those connected
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: with knowledge of things. As the first of the problems connected
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: with knowledge of truths, let us examine the nature and scope of our
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: intuitive judgements.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: CHAPTER XI. ON INTUITIVE KNOWLEDGE
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: There is a common impression that everything that we believe ought to be
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: capable of proof, or at least of being shown to be highly probable. It
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is felt by many that a belief for which no reason can be given is an
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: unreasonable belief. In the main, this view is just. Almost all our
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: common beliefs are either inferred, or capable of being inferred, from
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: other beliefs which may be regarded as giving the reason for them. As a
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: rule, the reason has been forgotten, or has even never been consciously
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: present to our minds. Few of us ever ask ourselves, for example, what
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: reason there is to suppose the food we are just going to eat will not
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: turn out to be poison. Yet we feel, when challenged, that a perfectly
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: good reason could be found, even if we are not ready with it at the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: moment. And in this belief we are usually justified.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: But let us imagine some insistent Socrates, who, whatever reason we
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: give him, continues to demand a reason for the reason. We must sooner
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: or later, and probably before very long, be driven to a point where we
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: cannot find any further reason, and where it becomes almost certain that
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: no further reason is even theoretically discoverable. Starting with the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: common beliefs of daily life, we can be driven back from point to point,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: until we come to some general principle, or some instance of a general
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: principle, which seems luminously evident, and is not itself capable
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of being deduced from anything more evident. In most questions of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: daily life, such as whether our food is likely to be nourishing and not
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: poisonous, we shall be driven back to the inductive principle, which we
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: discussed in Chapter VI. But beyond that, there seems to be no further
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: regress. The principle itself is constantly used in our reasoning,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: sometimes consciously, sometimes unconsciously; but there is no
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: reasoning which, starting from some simpler self-evident principle,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: leads us to the principle of induction as its conclusion. And the same
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: holds for other logical principles. Their truth is evident to us, and we
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: employ them in constructing demonstrations; but they themselves, or at
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: least some of them, are incapable of demonstration.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Self-evidence, however, is not confined to those among general
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: principles which are incapable of proof. When a certain number of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: logical principles have been admitted, the rest can be deduced from
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: them; but the propositions deduced are often just as self-evident as
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: those that were assumed without proof. All arithmetic, moreover, can
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: be deduced from the general principles of logic, yet the simple
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: propositions of arithmetic, such as 'two and two are four', are just as
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: self-evident as the principles of logic.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: It would seem, also, though this is more disputable, that there are some
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: self-evident ethical principles, such as 'we ought to pursue what is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: good'.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: It should be observed that, in all cases of general principles,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: particular instances, dealing with familiar things, are more evident
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: than the general principle. For example, the law of contradiction states
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: that nothing can both have a certain property and not have it. This is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: evident as soon as it is understood, but it is not so evident as that a
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: particular rose which we see cannot be both red and not red. (It is of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: course possible that parts of the rose may be red and parts not red, or
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: that the rose may be of a shade of pink which we hardly know whether to
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: call red or not; but in the former case it is plain that the rose as a
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: whole is not red, while in the latter case the answer is theoretically
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: definite as soon as we have decided on a precise definition of 'red'.)
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: It is usually through particular instances that we come to be able to
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: see the general principle. Only those who are practised in dealing with
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: abstractions can readily grasp a general principle without the help of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: instances.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: In addition to general principles, the other kind of self-evident truths
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: are those immediately derived from sensation. We will call such truths
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: 'truths of perception', and the judgements expressing them we will
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: call 'judgements of perception'. But here a certain amount of care
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is required in getting at the precise nature of the truths that are
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: self-evident. The actual sense-data are neither true nor false. A
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: particular patch of colour which I see, for example, simply exists: it
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is not the sort of thing that is true or false. It is true that there is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: such a patch, true that it has a certain shape and degree of brightness,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: true that it is surrounded by certain other colours. But the patch
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: itself, like everything else in the world of sense, is of a radically
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: different kind from the things that are true or false, and therefore
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: cannot properly be said to be _true_. Thus whatever self-evident truths
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: may be obtained from our senses must be different from the sense-data
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: from which they are obtained.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: It would seem that there are two kinds of self-evident truths of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: perception, though perhaps in the last analysis the two kinds may
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: coalesce. First, there is the kind which simply asserts the _existence_
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of the sense-datum, without in any way analysing it. We see a patch
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of red, and we judge 'there is such-and-such a patch of red', or more
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: strictly 'there is that'; this is one kind of intuitive judgement of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: perception. The other kind arises when the object of sense is complex,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and we subject it to some degree of analysis. If, for instance, we see a
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: _round_ patch of red, we may judge 'that patch of red is round'. This is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: again a judgement of perception, but it differs from our previous kind.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: In our present kind we have a single sense-datum which has both colour
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and shape: the colour is red and the shape is round. Our judgement
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: analyses the datum into colour and shape, and then recombines them by
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: stating that the red colour is round in shape. Another example of this
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: kind of judgement is 'this is to the right of that', where 'this'
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and 'that' are seen simultaneously. In this kind of judgement the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: sense-datum contains constituents which have some relation to each
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: other, and the judgement asserts that these constituents have this
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: relation.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Another class of intuitive judgements, analogous to those of sense and
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: yet quite distinct from them, are judgements of _memory_. There is some
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: danger of confusion as to the nature of memory, owing to the fact that
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: memory of an object is apt to be accompanied by an image of the object,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and yet the image cannot be what constitutes memory. This is easily seen
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: by merely noticing that the image is in the present, whereas what is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: remembered is known to be in the past. Moreover, we are certainly able
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to some extent to compare our image with the object remembered, so
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: that we often know, within somewhat wide limits, how far our image is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: accurate; but this would be impossible, unless the object, as opposed to
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the image, were in some way before the mind. Thus the essence of memory
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is not constituted by the image, but by having immediately before the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: mind an object which is recognized as past. But for the fact of memory
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: in this sense, we should not know that there ever was a past at all,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: nor should we be able to understand the word 'past', any more than a man
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: born blind can understand the word 'light'. Thus there must be intuitive
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: judgements of memory, and it is upon them, ultimately, that all our
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: knowledge of the past depends.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: The case of memory, however, raises a difficulty, for it is notoriously
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: fallacious, and thus throws doubt on the trustworthiness of intuitive
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: judgements in general. This difficulty is no light one. But let us
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: first narrow its scope as far as possible. Broadly speaking, memory is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: trustworthy in proportion to the vividness of the experience and to its
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: nearness in time. If the house next door was struck by lightning half a
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: minute ago, my memory of what I saw and heard will be so reliable that
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: it would be preposterous to doubt whether there had been a flash at
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: all. And the same applies to less vivid experiences, so long as they are
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: recent. I am absolutely certain that half a minute ago I was sitting in
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the same chair in which I am sitting now. Going backward over the day,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: I find things of which I am quite certain, other things of which I am
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: almost certain, other things of which I can become certain by thought
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and by calling up attendant circumstances, and some things of which I
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: am by no means certain. I am quite certain that I ate my breakfast this
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: morning, but if I were as indifferent to my breakfast as a philosopher
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: should be, I should be doubtful. As to the conversation at breakfast,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: I can recall some of it easily, some with an effort, some only with a
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: large element of doubt, and some not at all. Thus there is a continual
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: gradation in the degree of self-evidence of what I remember, and a
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: corresponding gradation in the trustworthiness of my memory.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Thus the first answer to the difficulty of fallacious memory is to say
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: that memory has degrees of self-evidence, and that these correspond
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to the degrees of its trustworthiness, reaching a limit of perfect
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: self-evidence and perfect trustworthiness in our memory of events which
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: are recent and vivid.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: It would seem, however, that there are cases of very firm belief in a
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: memory which is wholly false. It is probable that, in these cases, what
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is really remembered, in the sense of being immediately before the mind,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is something other than what is falsely believed in, though something
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: generally associated with it. George IV is said to have at last believed
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: that he was at the battle of Waterloo, because he had so often said that
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: he was. In this case, what was immediately remembered was his repeated
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: assertion; the belief in what he was asserting (if it existed) would
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: be produced by association with the remembered assertion, and would
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: therefore not be a genuine case of memory. It would seem that cases of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: fallacious memory can probably all be dealt with in this way, i.e. they
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: can be shown to be not cases of memory in the strict sense at all.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: One important point about self-evidence is made clear by the case of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: memory, and that is, that self-evidence has degrees: it is not a quality
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: which is simply present or absent, but a quality which may be more or
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: less present, in gradations ranging from absolute certainty down to an
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: almost imperceptible faintness. Truths of perception and some of the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: principles of logic have the very highest degree of self-evidence;
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: truths of immediate memory have an almost equally high degree. The
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: inductive principle has less self-evidence than some of the other
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: principles of logic, such as 'what follows from a true premiss must be
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: true'. Memories have a diminishing self-evidence as they become remoter
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and fainter; the truths of logic and mathematics have (broadly speaking)
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: less self-evidence as they become more complicated. Judgements of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: intrinsic ethical or aesthetic value are apt to have some self-evidence,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: but not much.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Degrees of self-evidence are important in the theory of knowledge,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: since, if propositions may (as seems likely) have some degree of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: self-evidence without being true, it will not be necessary to abandon
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: all connexion between self-evidence and truth, but merely to say that,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: where there is a conflict, the more self-evident proposition is to be
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: retained and the less self-evident rejected.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: It seems, however, highly probable that two different notions are
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: combined in 'self-evidence' as above explained; that one of them,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: which corresponds to the highest degree of self-evidence, is really an
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: infallible guarantee of truth, while the other, which corresponds to
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: all the other degrees, does not give an infallible guarantee, but only a
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: greater or less presumption. This, however, is only a suggestion, which
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: we cannot as yet develop further. After we have dealt with the nature
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of truth, we shall return to the subject of self-evidence, in connexion
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: with the distinction between knowledge and error.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: CHAPTER XII. TRUTH AND FALSEHOOD
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Our knowledge of truths, unlike our knowledge of things, has an
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: opposite, namely _error_. So far as things are concerned, we may know
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: them or not know them, but there is no positive state of mind which can
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: be described as erroneous knowledge of things, so long, at any rate,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: as we confine ourselves to knowledge by acquaintance. Whatever we are
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: acquainted with must be something; we may draw wrong inferences from
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: our acquaintance, but the acquaintance itself cannot be deceptive. Thus
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: there is no dualism as regards acquaintance. But as regards knowledge of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: truths, there is a dualism. We may believe what is false as well as
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: what is true. We know that on very many subjects different people
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: hold different and incompatible opinions: hence some beliefs must be
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: erroneous. Since erroneous beliefs are often held just as strongly
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: as true beliefs, it becomes a difficult question how they are to be
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand
