text: distinguished from true beliefs. How are we to know, in a given case,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: that our belief is not erroneous? This is a question of the very
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: greatest difficulty, to which no completely satisfactory answer is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: possible. There is, however, a preliminary question which is rather less
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: difficult, and that is: What do we _mean_ by truth and falsehood? It is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: this preliminary question which is to be considered in this chapter. In
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: this chapter we are not asking how we can know whether a belief is true
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: or false: we are asking what is meant by the question whether a belief
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is true or false. It is to be hoped that a clear answer to this question
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: may help us to obtain an answer to the question what beliefs are
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: true, but for the present we ask only 'What is truth?' and 'What is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: falsehood?' not 'What beliefs are true?' and 'What beliefs are false?'
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: It is very important to keep these different questions entirely
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: separate, since any confusion between them is sure to produce an answer
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: which is not really applicable to either.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: There are three points to observe in the attempt to discover the nature
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of truth, three requisites which any theory must fulfil.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: (1) Our theory of truth must be such as to admit of its opposite,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: falsehood. A good many philosophers have failed adequately to satisfy
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: this condition: they have constructed theories according to which all
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: our thinking ought to have been true, and have then had the greatest
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: difficulty in finding a place for falsehood. In this respect our theory
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of belief must differ from our theory of acquaintance, since in the case
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of acquaintance it was not necessary to take account of any opposite.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: (2) It seems fairly evident that if there were no beliefs there could
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: be no falsehood, and no truth either, in the sense in which truth is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: correlative to falsehood. If we imagine a world of mere matter, there
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: would be no room for falsehood in such a world, and although it would
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: contain what may be called 'facts', it would not contain any truths, in
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the sense in which truths are things of the same kind as falsehoods.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: In fact, truth and falsehood are properties of beliefs and statements:
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: hence a world of mere matter, since it would contain no beliefs or
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: statements, would also contain no truth or falsehood.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: (3) But, as against what we have just said, it is to be observed that
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the truth or falsehood of a belief always depends upon something which
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: lies outside the belief itself. If I believe that Charles I died on the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: scaffold, I believe truly, not because of any intrinsic quality of my
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: belief, which could be discovered by merely examining the belief, but
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: because of an historical event which happened two and a half centuries
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: ago. If I believe that Charles I died in his bed, I believe falsely: no
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: degree of vividness in my belief, or of care in arriving at it, prevents
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: it from being false, again because of what happened long ago, and not
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: because of any intrinsic property of my belief. Hence, although truth
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and falsehood are properties of beliefs, they are properties dependent
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: upon the relations of the beliefs to other things, not upon any internal
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: quality of the beliefs.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: The third of the above requisites leads us to adopt the view--which has
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: on the whole been commonest among philosophers--that truth consists in
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: some form of correspondence between belief and fact. It is, however, by
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: no means an easy matter to discover a form of correspondence to which
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: there are no irrefutable objections. By this partly--and partly by the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: feeling that, if truth consists in a correspondence of thought with
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: something outside thought, thought can never know when truth has been
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: attained--many philosophers have been led to try to find some definition
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of truth which shall not consist in relation to something wholly outside
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: belief. The most important attempt at a definition of this sort is the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: theory that truth consists in _coherence_. It is said that the mark of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: falsehood is failure to cohere in the body of our beliefs, and that it
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is the essence of a truth to form part of the completely rounded system
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: which is The Truth.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: There is, however, a great difficulty in this view, or rather two great
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: difficulties. The first is that there is no reason to suppose that
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: only _one_ coherent body of beliefs is possible. It may be that, with
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: sufficient imagination, a novelist might invent a past for the world
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: that would perfectly fit on to what we know, and yet be quite different
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: from the real past. In more scientific matters, it is certain that there
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: are often two or more hypotheses which account for all the known facts
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: on some subject, and although, in such cases, men of science endeavour
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to find facts which will rule out all the hypotheses except one, there
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is no reason why they should always succeed.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: In philosophy, again, it seems not uncommon for two rival hypotheses
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to be both able to account for all the facts. Thus, for example, it is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: possible that life is one long dream, and that the outer world has only
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: that degree of reality that the objects of dreams have; but although
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: such a view does not seem inconsistent with known facts, there is no
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: reason to prefer it to the common-sense view, according to which other
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: people and things do really exist. Thus coherence as the definition
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of truth fails because there is no proof that there can be only one
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: coherent system.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: The other objection to this definition of truth is that it assumes the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: meaning of 'coherence' known, whereas, in fact, 'coherence' presupposes
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the truth of the laws of logic. Two propositions are coherent when both
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: may be true, and are incoherent when one at least must be false. Now in
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: order to know whether two propositions can both be true, we must
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: know such truths as the law of contradiction. For example, the two
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: propositions, 'this tree is a beech' and 'this tree is not a beech',
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: are not coherent, because of the law of contradiction. But if the law of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: contradiction itself were subjected to the test of coherence, we should
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: find that, if we choose to suppose it false, nothing will any longer
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: be incoherent with anything else. Thus the laws of logic supply the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: skeleton or framework within which the test of coherence applies, and
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: they themselves cannot be established by this test.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: For the above two reasons, coherence cannot be accepted as giving the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: _meaning_ of truth, though it is often a most important _test_ of truth
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: after a certain amount of truth has become known.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Hence we are driven back to _correspondence with fact_ as constituting
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the nature of truth. It remains to define precisely what we mean by
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: 'fact', and what is the nature of the correspondence which must subsist
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: between belief and fact, in order that belief may be true.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: In accordance with our three requisites, we have to seek a theory of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: truth which (1) allows truth to have an opposite, namely falsehood, (2)
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: makes truth a property of beliefs, but (3) makes it a property wholly
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: dependent upon the relation of the beliefs to outside things.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: The necessity of allowing for falsehood makes it impossible to regard
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: belief as a relation of the mind to a single object, which could be said
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to be what is believed. If belief were so regarded, we should find that,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: like acquaintance, it would not admit of the opposition of truth and
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: falsehood, but would have to be always true. This may be made clear
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: by examples. Othello believes falsely that Desdemona loves Cassio. We
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: cannot say that this belief consists in a relation to a single object,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: 'Desdemona's love for Cassio', for if there were such an object, the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: belief would be true. There is in fact no such object, and therefore
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Othello cannot have any relation to such an object. Hence his belief
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: cannot possibly consist in a relation to this object.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: It might be said that his belief is a relation to a different object,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: namely 'that Desdemona loves Cassio'; but it is almost as difficult to
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: suppose that there is such an object as this, when Desdemona does not
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: love Cassio, as it was to suppose that there is 'Desdemona's love for
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Cassio'. Hence it will be better to seek for a theory of belief which
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: does not make it consist in a relation of the mind to a single object.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: It is common to think of relations as though they always held between
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: two terms, but in fact this is not always the case. Some relations
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: demand three terms, some four, and so on. Take, for instance, the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: relation 'between'. So long as only two terms come in, the relation
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: 'between' is impossible: three terms are the smallest number that render
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: it possible. York is between London and Edinburgh; but if London and
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Edinburgh were the only places in the world, there could be nothing
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: which was between one place and another. Similarly _jealousy_ requires
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: three people: there can be no such relation that does not involve three
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: at least. Such a proposition as 'A wishes B to promote C's marriage with
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: D' involves a relation of four terms; that is to say, A and B and C and
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: D all come in, and the relation involved cannot be expressed otherwise
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: than in a form involving all four. Instances might be multiplied
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: indefinitely, but enough has been said to show that there are relations
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: which require more than two terms before they can occur.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: The relation involved in _judging_ or _believing_ must, if falsehood is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to be duly allowed for, be taken to be a relation between several terms,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: not between two. When Othello believes that Desdemona loves Cassio, he
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: must not have before his mind a single object, 'Desdemona's love for
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Cassio', or 'that Desdemona loves Cassio ', for that would require that
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: there should be objective falsehoods, which subsist independently of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: any minds; and this, though not logically refutable, is a theory to be
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: avoided if possible. Thus it is easier to account for falsehood if
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: we take judgement to be a relation in which the mind and the various
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: objects concerned all occur severally; that is to say, Desdemona and
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: loving and Cassio must all be terms in the relation which subsists when
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Othello believes that Desdemona loves Cassio. This relation, therefore,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is a relation of four terms, since Othello also is one of the terms of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the relation. When we say that it is a relation of four terms, we do not
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: mean that Othello has a certain relation to Desdemona, and has the same
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: relation to loving and also to Cassio. This may be true of some other
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: relation than believing; but believing, plainly, is not a relation which
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Othello has to _each_ of the three terms concerned, but to _all_ of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: them together: there is only one example of the relation of believing
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: involved, but this one example knits together four terms. Thus the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: actual occurrence, at the moment when Othello is entertaining his
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: belief, is that the relation called 'believing' is knitting together
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: into one complex whole the four terms Othello, Desdemona, loving, and
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Cassio. What is called belief or judgement is nothing but this relation
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of believing or judging, which relates a mind to several things other
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: than itself. An _act_ of belief or of judgement is the occurrence
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: between certain terms at some particular time, of the relation of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: believing or judging.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: We are now in a position to understand what it is that distinguishes a
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: true judgement from a false one. For this purpose we will adopt certain
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: definitions. In every act of judgement there is a mind which judges, and
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: there are terms concerning which it judges. We will call the mind the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: _subject_ in the judgement, and the remaining terms the _objects_. Thus,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: when Othello judges that Desdemona loves Cassio, Othello is the subject,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: while the objects are Desdemona and loving and Cassio. The subject and
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the objects together are called the _constituents_ of the judgement.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: It will be observed that the relation of judging has what is called a
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: 'sense' or 'direction'. We may say, metaphorically, that it puts its
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: objects in a certain _order_, which we may indicate by means of the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: order of the words in the sentence. (In an inflected language, the same
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: thing will be indicated by inflections, e.g. by the difference between
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: nominative and accusative.) Othello's judgement that Cassio loves
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Desdemona differs from his judgement that Desdemona loves Cassio, in
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: spite of the fact that it consists of the same constituents, because the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: relation of judging places the constituents in a different order in the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: two cases. Similarly, if Cassio judges that Desdemona loves Othello,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the constituents of the judgement are still the same, but their order is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: different. This property of having a 'sense' or 'direction' is one which
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the relation of judging shares with all other relations. The 'sense'
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of relations is the ultimate source of order and series and a host of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: mathematical concepts; but we need not concern ourselves further with
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: this aspect.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: We spoke of the relation called 'judging' or 'believing' as knitting
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: together into one complex whole the subject and the objects. In this
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: respect, judging is exactly like every other relation. Whenever a
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: relation holds between two or more terms, it unites the terms into a
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: complex whole. If Othello loves Desdemona, there is such a complex whole
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: as 'Othello's love for Desdemona'. The terms united by the relation may
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: be themselves complex, or may be simple, but the whole which results
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: from their being united must be complex. Wherever there is a relation
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: which relates certain terms, there is a complex object formed of the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: union of those terms; and conversely, wherever there is a complex
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: object, there is a relation which relates its constituents. When an act
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of believing occurs, there is a complex, in which 'believing' is the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: uniting relation, and subject and objects are arranged in a certain
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: order by the 'sense' of the relation of believing. Among the objects,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: as we saw in considering 'Othello believes that Desdemona loves Cassio',
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: one must be a relation--in this instance, the relation 'loving'. But
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: this relation, as it occurs in the act of believing, is not the relation
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: which creates the unity of the complex whole consisting of the subject
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and the objects. The relation 'loving', as it occurs in the act of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: believing, is one of the objects--it is a brick in the structure, not
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the cement. The cement is the relation 'believing'. When the belief is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: _true_, there is another complex unity, in which the relation which was
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: one of the objects of the belief relates the other objects. Thus, e.g.,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: if Othello believes _truly_ that Desdemona loves Cassio, then there is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: a complex unity, 'Desdemona's love for Cassio', which is composed
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: exclusively of the _objects_ of the belief, in the same order as they
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: had in the belief, with the relation which was one of the objects
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: occurring now as the cement that binds together the other objects of the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: belief. On the other hand, when a belief is _false_, there is no such
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: complex unity composed only of the objects of the belief. If Othello
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: believes _falsely_ that Desdemona loves Cassio, then there is no such
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: complex unity as 'Desdemona's love for Cassio'.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Thus a belief is _true_ when it _corresponds_ to a certain associated
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: complex, and _false_ when it does not. Assuming, for the sake of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: definiteness, that the objects of the belief are two terms and a
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: relation, the terms being put in a certain order by the 'sense' of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the believing, then if the two terms in that order are united by the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: relation into a complex, the belief is true; if not, it is false. This
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: constitutes the definition of truth and falsehood that we were in search
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of. Judging or believing is a certain complex unity of which a mind is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: a constituent; if the remaining constituents, taken in the order which
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: they have in the belief, form a complex unity, then the belief is true;
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: if not, it is false.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Thus although truth and falsehood are properties of beliefs, yet they
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: are in a sense extrinsic properties, for the condition of the truth of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: a belief is something not involving beliefs, or (in general) any mind
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: at all, but only the _objects_ of the belief. A mind, which believes,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: believes truly when there is a _corresponding_ complex not involving the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: mind, but only its objects. This correspondence ensures truth, and its
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: absence entails falsehood. Hence we account simultaneously for the two
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: facts that beliefs (a) depend on minds for their _existence_, (b) do not
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: depend on minds for their _truth_.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: We may restate our theory as follows: If we take such a belief as
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: 'Othello believes that Desdemona loves Cassio', we will call Desdemona
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and Cassio the _object-terms_, and loving the _object-relation_. If
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: there is a complex unity 'Desdemona's love for Cassio', consisting of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the object-terms related by the object-relation in the same order as
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: they have in the belief, then this complex unity is called the _fact
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: corresponding to the belief_. Thus a belief is true when there is a
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: corresponding fact, and is false when there is no corresponding fact.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: It will be seen that minds do not _create_ truth or falsehood. They
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: create beliefs, but when once the beliefs are created, the mind cannot
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: make them true or false, except in the special case where they concern
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: future things which are within the power of the person believing, such
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: as catching trains. What makes a belief true is a _fact_, and this fact
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: does not (except in exceptional cases) in any way involve the mind of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the person who has the belief.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Having now decided what we _mean_ by truth and falsehood, we have next
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to consider what ways there are of knowing whether this or that belief
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is true or false. This consideration will occupy the next chapter.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: CHAPTER XIII. KNOWLEDGE, ERROR, AND PROBABLE OPINION
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: The question as to what we mean by truth and falsehood, which we
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: considered in the preceding chapter, is of much less interest than the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: question as to how we can know what is true and what is false. This
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: question will occupy us in the present chapter. There can be no doubt
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: that _some_ of our beliefs are erroneous; thus we are led to inquire
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: what certainty we can ever have that such and such a belief is not
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: erroneous. In other words, can we ever _know_ anything at all, or do we
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: merely sometimes by good luck believe what is true? Before we can attack
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: this question, we must, however, first decide what we mean by 'knowing',
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and this question is not so easy as might be supposed.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: At first sight we might imagine that knowledge could be defined as 'true
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: belief'. When what we believe is true, it might be supposed that we had
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: achieved a knowledge of what we believe. But this would not accord
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: with the way in which the word is commonly used. To take a very trivial
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: instance: If a man believes that the late Prime Minister's last name
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: began with a B, he believes what is true, since the late Prime Minister
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: was Sir Henry Campbell Bannerman. But if he believes that Mr. Balfour
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: was the late Prime Minister, he will still believe that the late Prime
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Minister's last name began with a B, yet this belief, though true,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: would not be thought to constitute knowledge. If a newspaper, by an
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: intelligent anticipation, announces the result of a battle before any
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: telegram giving the result has been received, it may by good fortune
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: announce what afterwards turns out to be the right result, and it may
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: produce belief in some of its less experienced readers. But in spite of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the truth of their belief, they cannot be said to have knowledge. Thus
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: it is clear that a true belief is not knowledge when it is deduced from
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: a false belief.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: In like manner, a true belief cannot be called knowledge when it is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: deduced by a fallacious process of reasoning, even if the premisses from
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: which it is deduced are true. If I know that all Greeks are men and that
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Socrates was a man, and I infer that Socrates was a Greek, I cannot be
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: said to _know_ that Socrates was a Greek, because, although my premisses
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and my conclusion are true, the conclusion does not follow from the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: premisses.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: But are we to say that nothing is knowledge except what is validly
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: deduced from true premisses? Obviously we cannot say this. Such a
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: definition is at once too wide and too narrow. In the first place, it is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: too wide, because it is not enough that our premisses should be _true_,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: they must also be _known_. The man who believes that Mr. Balfour was the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: late Prime Minister may proceed to draw valid deductions from the true
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: premiss that the late Prime Minister's name began with a B, but he
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: cannot be said to _know_ the conclusions reached by these deductions.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Thus we shall have to amend our definition by saying that knowledge
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is what is validly deduced from _known_ premisses. This, however, is a
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: circular definition: it assumes that we already know what is meant
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: by 'known premisses'. It can, therefore, at best define one sort
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of knowledge, the sort we call derivative, as opposed to intuitive
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: knowledge. We may say: '_Derivative_ knowledge is what is validly
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: deduced from premisses known intuitively'. In this statement there is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: no formal defect, but it leaves the definition of _intuitive_ knowledge
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: still to seek.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Leaving on one side, for the moment, the question of intuitive
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: knowledge, let us consider the above suggested definition of derivative
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: knowledge. The chief objection to it is that it unduly limits knowledge.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: It constantly happens that people entertain a true belief, which has
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: grown up in them because of some piece of intuitive knowledge from which
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: it is capable of being validly inferred, but from which it has not, as a
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: matter of fact, been inferred by any logical process.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Take, for example, the beliefs produced by reading. If the newspapers
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: announce the death of the King, we are fairly well justified in
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: believing that the King is dead, since this is the sort of announcement
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: which would not be made if it were false. And we are quite amply
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: justified in believing that the newspaper asserts that the King is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: dead. But here the intuitive knowledge upon which our belief is based
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is knowledge of the existence of sense-data derived from looking at
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the print which gives the news. This knowledge scarcely rises into
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: consciousness, except in a person who cannot read easily. A child may be
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: aware of the shapes of the letters, and pass gradually and painfully to
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: a realization of their meaning. But anybody accustomed to reading
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: passes at once to what the letters mean, and is not aware, except on
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: reflection, that he has derived this knowledge from the sense-data
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: called seeing the printed letters. Thus although a valid inference from
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the-letters to their meaning is possible, and _could_ be performed
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: by the reader, it is not in fact performed, since he does not in fact
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: perform any operation which can be called logical inference. Yet
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: it would be absurd to say that the reader does not _know_ that the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: newspaper announces the King's death.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: We must, therefore, admit as derivative knowledge whatever is the result
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of intuitive knowledge even if by mere association, provided there _is_
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: a valid logical connexion, and the person in question could become aware
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of this connexion by reflection. There are in fact many ways, besides
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: logical inference, by which we pass from one belief to another: the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: passage from the print to its meaning illustrates these ways. These
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: ways may be called 'psychological inference'. We shall, then, admit such
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: psychological inference as a means of obtaining derivative knowledge,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: provided there is a discoverable logical inference which runs parallel
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to the psychological inference. This renders our definition of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: derivative knowledge less precise than we could wish, since the word
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: 'discoverable' is vague: it does not tell us how much reflection may be
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: needed in order to make the discovery. But in fact 'knowledge' is not a
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: precise conception: it merges into 'probable opinion', as we shall
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: see more fully in the course of the present chapter. A very precise
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: definition, therefore, should not be sought, since any such definition
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: must be more or less misleading.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: The chief difficulty in regard to knowledge, however, does not arise
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: over derivative knowledge, but over intuitive knowledge. So long as we
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: are dealing with derivative knowledge, we have the test of intuitive
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: knowledge to fall back upon. But in regard to intuitive beliefs, it is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: by no means easy to discover any criterion by which to distinguish
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: some as true and others as erroneous. In this question it is scarcely
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: possible to reach any very precise result: all our knowledge of truths
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is infected with some degree of doubt, and a theory which ignored this
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: fact would be plainly wrong. Something may be done, however, to mitigate
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the difficulties of the question.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Our theory of truth, to begin with, supplies the possibility of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: distinguishing certain truths as _self-evident_ in a sense which ensures
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: infallibility. When a belief is true, we said, there is a corresponding
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: fact, in which the several objects of the belief form a single complex.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: The belief is said to constitute _knowledge_ of this fact, provided
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: it fulfils those further somewhat vague conditions which we have been
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: considering in the present chapter. But in regard to any fact, besides
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the knowledge constituted by belief, we may also have the kind of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: knowledge constituted by _perception_ (taking this word in its widest
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: possible sense). For example, if you know the hour of the sunset,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: you can at that hour know the fact that the sun is setting: this is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: knowledge of the fact by way of knowledge of _truths_; but you can also,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: if the weather is fine, look to the west and actually see the setting
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: sun: you then know the same fact by the way of knowledge of _things_.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Thus in regard to any complex fact, there are, theoretically, two ways
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: in which it may be known: (1) by means of a judgement, in which its
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: several parts are judged to be related as they are in fact related; (2)
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: by means of _acquaintance_ with the complex fact itself, which may (in a
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: large sense) be called perception, though it is by no means confined to
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: objects of the senses. Now it will be observed that the second way of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: knowing a complex fact, the way of acquaintance, is only possible when
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: there really is such a fact, while the first way, like all judgement,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is liable to error. The second way gives us the complex whole, and is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: therefore only possible when its parts do actually have that relation
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: which makes them combine to form such a complex. The first way, on the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: contrary, gives us the parts and the relation severally, and demands
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: only the reality of the parts and the relation: the relation may not
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: relate those parts in that way, and yet the judgement may occur.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: It will be remembered that at the end of Chapter XI we suggested that
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: there might be two kinds of self-evidence, one giving an absolute
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: guarantee of truth, the other only a partial guarantee. These two kinds
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: can now be distinguished.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: We may say that a truth is self-evident, in the first and most absolute
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: sense, when we have acquaintance with the fact which corresponds to
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the truth. When Othello believes that Desdemona loves Cassio, the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: corresponding fact, if his belief were true, would be 'Desdemona's
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: love for Cassio'. This would be a fact with which no one could have
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: acquaintance except Desdemona; hence in the sense of self-evidence that
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: we are considering, the truth that Desdemona loves Cassio (if it were
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: a truth) could only be self-evident to Desdemona. All mental facts, and
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: all facts concerning sense-data, have this same privacy: there is only
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: one person to whom they can be self-evident in our present sense, since
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: there is only one person who can be acquainted with the mental things
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: or the sense-data concerned. Thus no fact about any particular existing
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: thing can be self-evident to more than one person. On the other hand,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: facts about universals do not have this privacy. Many minds may be
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: acquainted with the same universals; hence a relation between universals
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: may be known by acquaintance to many different people. In all cases
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: where we know by acquaintance a complex fact consisting of certain terms
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: in a certain relation, we say that the truth that these terms are so
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: related has the first or absolute kind of self-evidence, and in these
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: cases the judgement that the terms are so related _must_ be true. Thus
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: this sort of self-evidence is an absolute guarantee of truth.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: But although this sort of self-evidence is an absolute guarantee of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: truth, it does not enable us to be _absolutely_ certain, in the case of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: any given judgement, that the judgement in question is true. Suppose
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: we first perceive the sun shining, which is a complex fact, and thence
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: proceed to make the judgement 'the sun is shining'. In passing from
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the perception to the judgement, it is necessary to analyse the given
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: complex fact: we have to separate out 'the sun' and 'shining' as
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: constituents of the fact. In this process it is possible to commit
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: an error; hence even where a _fact_ has the first or absolute kind of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: self-evidence, a judgement believed to correspond to the fact is not
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: absolutely infallible, because it may not really correspond to the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: fact. But if it does correspond (in the sense explained in the preceding
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: chapter), then it _must_ be true.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: The second sort of self-evidence will be that which belongs to
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: judgements in the first instance, and is not derived from direct
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: perception of a fact as a single complex whole. This second kind of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: self-evidence will have degrees, from the very highest degree down to a
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: bare inclination in favour of the belief. Take, for example, the case of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: a horse trotting away from us along a hard road. At first our certainty
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: that we hear the hoofs is complete; gradually, if we listen intently,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: there comes a moment when we think perhaps it was imagination or the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: blind upstairs or our own heartbeats; at last we become doubtful whether
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: there was any noise at all; then we _think_ we no longer hear anything,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and at last we _know_ we no longer hear anything. In this process, there
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is a continual gradation of self-evidence, from the highest degree to
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the least, not in the sense-data themselves, but in the judgements based
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: on them.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Or again: Suppose we are comparing two shades of colour, one blue and
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: one green. We can be quite sure they are different shades of colour; but
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: if the green colour is gradually altered to be more and more like the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: blue, becoming first a blue-green, then a greeny-blue, then blue,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: there will come a moment when we are doubtful whether we can see any
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: difference, and then a moment when we know that we cannot see any
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: difference. The same thing happens in tuning a musical instrument, or in
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: any other case where there is a continuous gradation. Thus self-evidence
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of this sort is a matter of degree; and it seems plain that the higher
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: degrees are more to be trusted than the lower degrees.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: In derivative knowledge our ultimate premisses must have some degree of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: self-evidence, and so must their connexion with the conclusions deduced
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: from them. Take for example a piece of reasoning in geometry. It is not
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: enough that the axioms from which we start should be self-evident: it
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is necessary also that, at each step in the reasoning, the connexion of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: premiss and conclusion should be self-evident. In difficult reasoning,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: this connexion has often only a very small degree of self-evidence;
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: hence errors of reasoning are not improbable where the difficulty is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: great.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: From what has been said it is evident that, both as regards intuitive
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: knowledge and as regards derivative knowledge, if we assume that
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: intuitive knowledge is trustworthy in proportion to the degree of its
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: self-evidence, there will be a gradation in trustworthiness, from the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: existence of noteworthy sense-data and the simpler truths of logic and
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: arithmetic, which may be taken as quite certain, down to judgements
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: which seem only just more probable than their opposites. What we firmly
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: believe, if it is true, is called _knowledge_, provided it is either
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: intuitive or inferred (logically or psychologically) from intuitive
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: knowledge from which it follows logically. What we firmly believe, if it
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is not true, is called _error_. What we firmly believe, if it is neither
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: knowledge nor error, and also what we believe hesitatingly, because it
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is, or is derived from, something which has not the highest degree of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: self-evidence, may be called _probable opinion_. Thus the greater
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: part of what would commonly pass as knowledge is more or less probable
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: opinion.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: In regard to probable opinion, we can derive great assistance from
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: _coherence_, which we rejected as the _definition_ of truth, but may
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: often use as a _criterion_. A body of individually probable opinions,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: if they are mutually coherent, become more probable than any one of them
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: would be individually. It is in this way that many scientific hypotheses
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: acquire their probability. They fit into a coherent system of probable
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: opinions, and thus become more probable than they would be in isolation.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: The same thing applies to general philosophical hypotheses. Often in a
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: single case such hypotheses may seem highly doubtful, while yet, when
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: we consider the order and coherence which they introduce into a mass of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: probable opinion, they become pretty nearly certain. This applies, in
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: particular, to such matters as the distinction between dreams and
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: waking life. If our dreams, night after night, were as coherent one with
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: another as our days, we should hardly know whether to believe the dreams
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: or the waking life. As it is, the test of coherence condemns the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: dreams and confirms the waking life. But this test, though it increases
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: probability where it is successful, never gives absolute certainty,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: unless there is certainty already at some point in the coherent system.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Thus the mere organization of probable opinion will never, by itself,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: transform it into indubitable knowledge.
