text: CHAPTER XIV. THE LIMITS OF PHILOSOPHICAL KNOWLEDGE
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: In all that we have said hitherto concerning philosophy, we have
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: scarcely touched on many matters that occupy a great space in the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: writings of most philosophers. Most philosophers--or, at any rate, very
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: many--profess to be able to prove, by _a priori_ metaphysical reasoning,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: such things as the fundamental dogmas of religion, the essential
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: rationality of the universe, the illusoriness of matter, the unreality
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of all evil, and so on. There can be no doubt that the hope of finding
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: reason to believe such theses as these has been the chief inspiration of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: many life-long students of philosophy. This hope, I believe, is vain. It
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: would seem that knowledge concerning the universe as a whole is not to
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: be obtained by metaphysics, and that the proposed proofs that, in virtue
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of the laws of logic such and such things _must_ exist and such and such
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: others cannot, are not capable of surviving a critical scrutiny. In
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: this chapter we shall briefly consider the kind of way in which such
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: reasoning is attempted, with a view to discovering whether we can hope
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: that it may be valid.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: The great representative, in modern times, of the kind of view which
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: we wish to examine, was Hegel (1770-1831). Hegel's philosophy is very
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: difficult, and commentators differ as to the true interpretation of it.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: According to the interpretation I shall adopt, which is that of many, if
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: not most, of the commentators and has the merit of giving an interesting
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and important type of philosophy, his main thesis is that everything
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: short of the Whole is obviously fragmentary, and obviously incapable of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: existing without the complement supplied by the rest of the world. Just
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: as a comparative anatomist, from a single bone, sees what kind of animal
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the whole must have been, so the metaphysician, according to Hegel,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: sees, from any one piece of reality, what the whole of reality must
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: be--at least in its large outlines. Every apparently separate piece of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: reality has, as it were, hooks which grapple it to the next piece;
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the next piece, in turn, has fresh hooks, and so on, until the whole
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: universe is reconstructed. This essential incompleteness appears,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: according to Hegel, equally in the world of thought and in the world of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: things. In the world of thought, if we take any idea which is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: abstract or incomplete, we find, on examination, that if we forget
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: its incompleteness, we become involved in contradictions; these
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: contradictions turn the idea in question into its opposite, or
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: antithesis; and in order to escape, we have to find a new, less
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: incomplete idea, which is the synthesis of our original idea and its
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: antithesis. This new idea, though less incomplete than the idea we
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: started with, will be found, nevertheless, to be still not wholly
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: complete, but to pass into its antithesis, with which it must be
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: combined in a new synthesis. In this way Hegel advances until he reaches
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the 'Absolute Idea', which, according to him, has no incompleteness,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: no opposite, and no need of further development. The Absolute Idea,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: therefore, is adequate to describe Absolute Reality; but all lower ideas
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: only describe reality as it appears to a partial view, not as it is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to one who simultaneously surveys the Whole. Thus Hegel reaches the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: conclusion that Absolute Reality forms one single harmonious system, not
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: in space or time, not in any degree evil, wholly rational, and wholly
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: spiritual. Any appearance to the contrary, in the world we know, can be
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: proved logically--so he believes--to be entirely due to our fragmentary
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: piecemeal view of the universe. If we saw the universe whole, as we may
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: suppose God sees it, space and time and matter and evil and all striving
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and struggling would disappear, and we should see instead an eternal
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: perfect unchanging spiritual unity.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: In this conception, there is undeniably something sublime, something to
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: which we could wish to yield assent. Nevertheless, when the arguments
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: in support of it are carefully examined, they appear to involve much
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: confusion and many unwarrantable assumptions. The fundamental tenet
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: upon which the system is built up is that what is incomplete must be not
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: self-subsistent, but must need the support of other things before it can
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: exist. It is held that whatever has relations to things outside itself
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: must contain some reference to those outside things in its own nature,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and could not, therefore, be what it is if those outside things did not
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: exist. A man's nature, for example, is constituted by his memories and
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the rest of his knowledge, by his loves and hatreds, and so on; thus,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: but for the objects which he knows or loves or hates, he could not be
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: what he is. He is essentially and obviously a fragment: taken as the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: sum-total of reality he would be self-contradictory.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: This whole point of view, however, turns upon the notion of the 'nature'
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of a thing, which seems to mean 'all the truths about the thing'. It is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of course the case that a truth which connects one thing with another
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: thing could not subsist if the other thing did not subsist. But a
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: truth about a thing is not part of the thing itself, although it must,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: according to the above usage, be part of the 'nature' of the thing.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: If we mean by a thing's 'nature' all the truths about the thing, then
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: plainly we cannot know a thing's 'nature' unless we know all the thing's
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: relations to all the other things in the universe. But if the word
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: 'nature' is used in this sense, we shall have to hold that the thing
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: may be known when its 'nature' is not known, or at any rate is not known
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: completely. There is a confusion, when this use of the word 'nature' is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: employed, between knowledge of things and knowledge of truths. We may
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: have knowledge of a thing by acquaintance even if we know very few
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: propositions about it--theoretically we need not know any propositions
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: about it. Thus, acquaintance with a thing does not involve knowledge of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: its 'nature' in the above sense. And although acquaintance with a thing
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is involved in our knowing any one proposition about a thing, knowledge
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of its 'nature', in the above sense, is not involved. Hence, (1)
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: acquaintance with a thing does not logically involve a knowledge of its
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: relations, and (2) a knowledge of some of its relations does not involve
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: a knowledge of all of its relations nor a knowledge of its 'nature' in
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the above sense. I may be acquainted, for example, with my toothache,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and this knowledge may be as complete as knowledge by acquaintance ever
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: can be, without knowing all that the dentist (who is not acquainted
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: with it) can tell me about its cause, and without therefore knowing its
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: 'nature' in the above sense. Thus the fact that a thing has relations
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: does not prove that its relations are logically necessary. That is to
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: say, from the mere fact that it is the thing it is we cannot deduce
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: that it must have the various relations which in fact it has. This only
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: _seems_ to follow because we know it already.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: It follows that we cannot prove that the universe as a whole forms a
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: single harmonious system such as Hegel believes that it forms. And if we
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: cannot prove this, we also cannot prove the unreality of space and time
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and matter and evil, for this is deduced by Hegel from the fragmentary
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and relational character of these things. Thus we are left to the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: piecemeal investigation of the world, and are unable to know the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: characters of those parts of the universe that are remote from our
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: experience. This result, disappointing as it is to those whose hopes
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: have been raised by the systems of philosophers, is in harmony with
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the inductive and scientific temper of our age, and is borne out by the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: whole examination of human knowledge which has occupied our previous
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: chapters.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Most of the great ambitious attempts of metaphysicians have proceeded by
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the attempt to prove that such and such apparent features of the actual
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: world were self-contradictory, and therefore could not be real. The
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: whole tendency of modern thought, however, is more and more in the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: direction of showing that the supposed contradictions were illusory, and
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: that very little can be proved _a priori_ from considerations of what
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: _must_ be. A good illustration of this is afforded by space and
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: time. Space and time appear to be infinite in extent, and infinitely
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: divisible. If we travel along a straight line in either direction, it
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is difficult to believe that we shall finally reach a last point,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: beyond which there is nothing, not even empty space. Similarly, if in
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: imagination we travel backwards or forwards in time, it is difficult to
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: believe that we shall reach a first or last time, with not even empty
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: time beyond it. Thus space and time appear to be infinite in extent.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Again, if we take any two points on a line, it seems evident that there
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: must be other points between them however small the distance between
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: them may be: every distance can be halved, and the halves can be halved
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: again, and so on _ad infinitum_. In time, similarly, however little
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: time may elapse between two moments, it seems evident that there will be
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: other moments between them. Thus space and time appear to be infinitely
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: divisible. But as against these apparent facts--infinite extent and
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: infinite divisibility--philosophers have advanced arguments tending to
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: show that there could be no infinite collections of things, and that
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: therefore the number of points in space, or of instants in time, must
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: be finite. Thus a contradiction emerged between the apparent nature of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: space and time and the supposed impossibility of infinite collections.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Kant, who first emphasized this contradiction, deduced the impossibility
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of space and time, which he declared to be merely subjective; and since
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: his time very many philosophers have believed that space and time are
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: mere appearance, not characteristic of the world as it really is. Now,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: however, owing to the labours of the mathematicians, notably Georg
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Cantor, it has appeared that the impossibility of infinite collections
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: was a mistake. They are not in fact self-contradictory, but only
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: contradictory of certain rather obstinate mental prejudices. Hence the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: reasons for regarding space and time as unreal have become inoperative,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and one of the great sources of metaphysical constructions is dried up.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: The mathematicians, however, have not been content with showing that
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: space as it is commonly supposed to be is possible; they have shown also
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: that many other forms of space are equally possible, so far as logic
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: can show. Some of Euclid's axioms, which appear to common sense to be
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: necessary, and were formerly supposed to be necessary by philosophers,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: are now known to derive their appearance of necessity from our mere
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: familiarity with actual space, and not from any _a priori_ logical
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: foundation. By imagining worlds in which these axioms are false, the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: mathematicians have used logic to loosen the prejudices of common
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: sense, and to show the possibility of spaces differing--some more, some
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: less--from that in which we live. And some of these spaces differ so
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: little from Euclidean space, where distances such as we can measure are
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: concerned, that it is impossible to discover by observation whether our
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: actual space is strictly Euclidean or of one of these other kinds.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Thus the position is completely reversed. Formerly it appeared that
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: experience left only one kind of space to logic, and logic showed this
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: one kind to be impossible. Now, logic presents many kinds of space as
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: possible apart from experience, and experience only partially decides
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: between them. Thus, while our knowledge of what is has become less
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: than it was formerly supposed to be, our knowledge of what may be is
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: enormously increased. Instead of being shut in within narrow walls, of
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: which every nook and cranny could be explored, we find ourselves in an
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: open world of free possibilities, where much remains unknown because
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: there is so much to know.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: What has happened in the case of space and time has happened, to some
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: extent, in other directions as well. The attempt to prescribe to the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: universe by means of _a priori_ principles has broken down; logic,
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: instead of being, as formerly, the bar to possibilities, has become the
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: great liberator of the imagination, presenting innumerable alternatives
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: which are closed to unreflective common sense, and leaving to experience

author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the task of deciding, where decision is possible, between the many
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: worlds which logic offers for our choice. Thus knowledge as to what
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: exists becomes limited to what we can learn from experience--not to
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: what we can actually experience, for, as we have seen, there is much
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: knowledge by description concerning things of which we have no direct
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

title: The Problems of Philosophy

text: infer an object of a certain sort as implied by our datum. Thus in

author: Russell, Bertrand

text: regard to physical objects, for example, the principle that sense-data

author: Russell, Bertrand

text: are signs of physical objects is itself a connexion of universals; and
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: it is only in virtue of this principle that experience enables us to
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: acquire knowledge concerning physical objects. The same applies to

text: CHAPTER XV. THE VALUE OF PHILOSOPHY
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Having now come to the end of our brief and very incomplete review of

author: Russell, Bertrand

title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

author: Russell, Bertrand

title: The Problems of Philosophy

text: indirectly, through its effects upon the lives of those who study it.
title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: It is in these effects, therefore, if anywhere, that the value of

title: The Problems of Philosophy
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: But further, if we are not to fail in our endeavour to determine the

author: Russell, Bertrand
